Value: Professor Abernathy works in the fields of federal civil procedure, civil rights, and comparative law.
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: His most recent book, Law in the United States (West Academic, 2021) (with Professor Markus Puder) explores US law as a topic of comparative law and legal processes.
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: He specializes in teaching American law to students from foreign legal backgrounds, as explored in “Law as an Item of Trade” in A Revolution in the International Rule of Law: Essays in Honor of Don Wallace Jr. (Borzu Sabahi ed., Juris Publishing, 2014).
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: Professor Abernathy was the Fulbright Professor of Law in Egypt in 1983-84, served as director of Georgetown University Law Center’s summer programs abroad (in Florence, Italy, and Heidelberg, Germany) from 1987-2000, and often lectures at law schools abroad (Italy, Switzerland, Argentina, and Germany).
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: Professor Abernathy is also the author of Civil Rights and Constitutional Litigation (West Publishing, multiple editions), the first edition of which was the first modern casebook on federal civil rights statutes.
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: He authored or co-authored Supreme Court briefs in major civil rights cases while serving at the Southern Poverty Law Center, including the brief for Sharon Frontiero in Frontiero v. Richardson.
Name: Charles F. Abernathy

Value: LL.B., University of Jordan, Ammam, Jordan; LL.M., University of Bristol, England; MA, University of York, York, England; S.J.D., Harvard.
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: Prior to joining the Law Center, Professor Abu-Odeh was a consulting assistant professor at Stanford Law School, where she taught Criminal Law, Comparative Family Law, Islamic Law, and a seminar entitled “Nations, Races, and Religion.”
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: Professor Abu-Odeh was a writing instructor in the Graduate Program and Coordinator of Special Academic Projects, Islamic Legal Studies Program, at Harvard Law School.
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: She worked at the World Bank as legal counsel in the Middle East/North Africa Division, Legal Department.
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: As an elections observer for the United Nations, South Africa, Professor Abu-Odeh participated in voter education, party monitoring, and election supervision during the period leading to the first democratic elections in South Africa.
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: Professor Abu-Odeh has written articles on Feminism and Islam.
Name: Lama Abu-Odeh

Value: Professor Arlyck teaches civil procedure, federal courts, and legal history.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: His scholarship investigates the federal courts’ early history, with a particular focus on their involvement in national governance between ratification of the Constitution and the Civil War.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: His scholarship has been or will be published in Law and History Review, Columbia Law Review, NYU Law Review, Notre Dame Law Review, and Brigham Young University Law Review.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: He is currently working on a book exploring the important role the federal courts played in early U.S. foreign relations.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, Professor Arlyck received a J.D. and Ph.D. in history from New York University, and he clerked for the Hon. Sonia Sotomayor on the Supreme Court of the United States and the Hon. Robert Katzmann on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: He also held academic fellowships at Columbia Law and NYU School of Law, and spent several years in private practice at Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe in New York.
Name: Kevin Arlyck

Value: Vicki Arroyo is the Executive Director of the Georgetown Climate Center based at Georgetown University Law Center, where she is also a Professor from Practice.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Arroyo serves as Special Advisor to the President of Georgetown University, and was previously Law Center’s Assistant Dean of Centers and Institutes.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Arroyo oversees the Georgetown Climate Center’s work at the nexus of climate and energy policy, supervising staff and student work on climate mitigation and adaptation at the state and federal level.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She teaches “experiential” environmental law courses to both law and public policy students.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She is also a member of the faculty steering committee for the Georgetown Environment Initiative, a cross-campus effort to advance the interdisciplinary study of the environment in relation to society, scientific understanding, and sound policy.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Arroyo served as the Law Center’s first Environmental Law Program Director where she helped develop and launch a new Environmental Law LLM degree program and oversaw all aspects of the program including admissions of students, counseling, and curricular development from 2013 – 2015 and still works closely with the program’s Director.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She previously served at the Pew Center on Global Climate Change, including as the Pew Center’s Vice President for Domestic Policy and General Counsel.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: For over a decade, she directed the Pew Center’s domestic policy program as well as managing the Center’s work on science, environmental impacts, adaptation, and economics.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Arroyo served as Managing Editor of the Center’s book, Climate Change: Science, Strategies, and Solutions.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: In addition to teaching at Georgetown Law, she has taught courses on environmental policy and climate change at Catholic University, George Mason University’s graduate public policy program, and Tulane Law School.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Previously, she practiced environmental law with Kilpatrick Stockton in Washington DC and other firms and served in two offices at U.S. EPA: the Office of Air and Radiation and the Office of Research and Development, where she reviewed development of standards under the Clean Air Act. From 1988 to 1991, she created and directed the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality’s policy office, and also served during some of that period as Governor Buddy Roemer’s environmental advisor.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Arroyo currently serves as Chair of the Executive Committee of the National Transportation Research Board (TRB) of the National Academy of Sciences and chaired TRB’s Resilience and Sustainability Task Force.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She serves on the Board of Advisors of the Institute of Transportation at UC Davis, and has testified before the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works on steps that states and cities are taking to reduce greenhouse gas pollution from transportation and to make communities more resilient to the serious consequences of climate change.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She previously served for seven years on the Advisory Board to the National Science Foundation’s Geosciences Directorate, and for three years on the Board of Trustees to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She helped develop California’s cap-and-trade system as a member of California’s Economics and Allocation Advisory Committee.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She has also held positions on the external advisory committee to the National Center for Atmospheric Research, and on several other federal panels, including those reviewing economic modeling of climate legislation (DOE’s Energy Information Administration) and on climate change adaptation along the Gulf Coast (Climate Change Science Program).
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She is Associate Editor of the journal Climate Policy and a member of the editorial board for The Georgetown Environmental Law Review (formerly The Georgetown International Law Review).
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: In 2018, Professor Arroyo was elected to the American College of Environmental Lawyers (ACOEL).
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: She holds a B.S. in biology, high honors, from Emory (double major in philosophy); a Masters of Public Administration from Harvard (receiving the Don K. Price award for academic achievement and commitment to public service, the top honors in her program), and a J.D., magna cum laude, from Georgetown Law, where she was Editor-in-Chief of The Georgetown International Environmental Law Review.
Name: Vicki A. Arroyo

Value: Professor Babcock served as general counsel to the National Audubon Society from 1987-91 and as deputy general counsel and Director of Audubon’s Public Lands and Water Program from 1981-87.
Name: Hope Babcock

Value: Previously, she was a partner with Blum, Nash & Railsback, where she focused on energy and environmental issues, and an associate at LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae where she represented utilities in the nuclear licensing process.
Name: Hope Babcock

Value: From 1977-79, she served as a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Energy and Minerals in the U.S. Department of the Interior.
Name: Hope Babcock

Value: Professor Babcock has taught environmental and natural resources law as a visiting professor at Pace University Law School and as an adjunct at the University of Pennsylvania, Yale, Catholic University, and Antioch law schools.
Name: Hope Babcock

Value: Professor Babcock was a member of the Standing Committee on Environmental Law of the American Bar Association, and served on the Clinton-Gore Transition Team.
Name: Hope Babcock

Value: Randy E. Barnett is the Patrick Hotung Professor of Constitutional Law at the Georgetown University Law Center and is Director of the Georgetown Center for the Constitution.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: After graduating from Northwestern University and Harvard Law School, he tried many felony cases as a prosecutor in the Cook County States’ Attorney’s Office in Chicago.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: A recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship in Constitutional Studies and the Bradley Prize, Professor Barnett has been a visiting professor at Penn, Northwestern and Harvard Law School.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: Professor Barnett’s publications includes twelve books, more than one hundred articles and reviews, as well as numerous op-eds.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: His most recent book is The Original Meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment: Its Letter and Spirit (2021) (with Evan Bernick).
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: His other books on the Constitution include: An Introduction to Constitutional Law: 100 Supreme Court Cases Everyone Should Know (2019) (with Josh Blackman);
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: Restoring the Lost Constitution: The Presumption of Liberty (2nd ed. 2013);
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: Our Republican Constitution: Securing the Liberty and Sovereignty of We the People (2016); and Constitutional Law: Cases in Context (4th ed. forthcoming 2022) (with Josh Blackman).
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: His books on contracts are The Oxford Introductions to U.S. Law: Contracts (2010) and Contracts: Cases and Doctrine (7th ed. 2021) (with Nate Oman).
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: And he is the author of The Structure of Liberty: Justice and the Rule of Law (2nd ed. 2014).
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: In 2004, he argued the medical marijuana case of Gonzalez v. Raich before the U.S. Supreme Court.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: In 2012, he was one of the lawyers representing the National Federation of Independent Business in its constitutional challenge to the Affordable Care Act in NFIB v. Sebelius.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: He’s appeared in numerous documentaries, including PBS’s Constitution USA with Peter Sagal and A More or Less Perfect Union with Judge Douglas Ginsburg; and he portrayed a prosecutor in the 2010 science-fiction feature film, InAlienable: The Movie.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: He blogs on the Volokh Conspiracy.
Name: Randy E. Barnett

Value: Secure Systems and Cryptology
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: My research focuses on the architecture and design of secure systems based on cryptographic techniques, analysis of secure systems against practical attack models, and on finding new cryptographic primitives and techniques.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: This work has led directly to several new cryptographic concepts, including: “Remotely-Keyed Encryption,” which allows the use of inexpensive, low-bandwidth secure hardware to protect high-bandwidth communication and stored data, “Atomic Proxy Cryptography,” which allows re-encryption by untrusted third parties, and “Master-Key Encryption,” which provides a systematic way to design (and study) ciphers with built-in “back doors.”
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: I am especially interested in the use of encryption to protect insecure systems such as the Internet.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: I was a designer of swipe, a predecessor of the now standard IPSEC protocol for protecting Internet traffic.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Another project, CFS, investigated and demonstrated the feasibility of including encryption as file system service.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Recently, I’ve applied cryptologic techniques to other areas, including the analysis of physical security systems; this work yielded a powerful and practical attack against virtually all commonly used master-keyed mechanical locks.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Trust Management    I coined the term, and am one of the inventors of, Trust Management, which provides the abstract layer in which a system decides whether to allow some potentially dangerous action.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: This work has led to two trust management languages, KeyNote and PolicyMaker, that provide tools for specifying policy, delegating authority, and controlling access.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: In addition to providing a useful framework for studying and proving security properties of distributed systems, our tools have been used to build powerful policy control mechanisms into several important applications, including the OpenBSD IPSEC implementation.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Technology and Public Policy    Cryptology and computer security have important relationships to vital areas of public policy, and my work has touched on these in several ways.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: In 1994, I discovered a serious flaw in the US Government’s “Clipper” encryption system, which had been proposed as a mechanism for the public to encrypt their data in a way that would still allow access by law enforcement.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: I have edited several influential reports on encryption policy, including the 1998 study of “key escrow” systems that demonstrated that such systems are inherently less secure and more expensive than systems without such a feature.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: This work contributed to the recent shift in U.S. encryption policy.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: More recently, I have been active in the analysis of the FBI’s “Carnivore”
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Internet wiretap system.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: I have testified before various comittees of the US Congress and European Parliament several times, providing technical perspective on the problems surrounding law enforcement and intelligence access to communications traffic and computer data.
Name: Matt Blaze

Value: Professor Susan Low Bloch joined the Georgetown Law Center faculty in 1982.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She teaches Constitutional Law I and II, Federal Courts, Communications Law, and a seminar on the Supreme Court.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Professor Bloch is the author of numerous articles in the areas of constitutional and administrative law and is the co-author of Inside the Supreme Court: The Institution and Its Procedures, published by West Publishing Company in 2008, and Supreme Court Politics:
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: The Institution and Its Procedures, published by West Publishing Company in 1994.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She has given lectures and interviews on a variety of topics, including impeachment, presidential immunity, historical overviews of the Supreme Court, the role of the Constitution in this country and its relevance for emerging democracies.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: In November 1998, she testified before the House Judiciary Committee as one of 19 constitutional law experts on what is an impeachable offense.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She also testified before the Senate on whether the President can be indicted and tried while in office.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She has participated in numerous international symposia organized by the Gruter Institute, giving papers on a variety of comparative law issues.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Widely quoted in the media, Professor Bloch has appeared on numerous television and radio programs on CNN, ABC, CBS, NBC, MSNBC, Fox News Channel, NPR, CBC, and USAID to discuss various topics including the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal, impeachment, and the independent counsel statute as well as pertinent constitutional issues of the moment.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Previously she was one of the expert panelists on “Inside DC with Fred Graham,” a weekly Court TV program that examined the latest developments in the law.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: In addition to teaching, Professor Bloch is a member of the American Law Institute, participant on the Twentieth Century Fund Project on the Judiciary, and a Fellow of the American Bar Foundation.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Locally, she has been a commissioner on the Judicial Nominating Committee for the District of Columbia Courts and has worked with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, serving on the Committee to Write the Oral History of the Circuit and on numerous committees for the D.C. Circuit Judicial Conference.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: In addition, she has been an editorial advisor to “Justice,” the Journal of the Department of Justice.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Professor Bloch is also active in the D.C. Bar, serving on the Ethics Committee, the Rules of Professional Conduct Review Committee, the Judicial Evaluation Committee, the Steering Committee of D.C. Bar Section for Courts, Lawyers, and the Administration of Justice, the Committee to Celebrate the Bicentennial of the Constitution, and the Administrative Law Section nominating committee.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She is also on the Board of the Institute for Public Representation and an advisor to students in the Public Interest Law Scholars Program at Georgetown.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Before joining the Law Center, Professor Bloch served as a law clerk for Justice Thurgood Marshall and for Judge Spottswood Robinson.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She also practiced law at Wilmer, Cutler, and Pickering for about four years.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Susan Bloch did her legal training at the University of Michigan Law School, where she graduated summa cum laude.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: Before that, she received graduate degrees in mathematics and computer science from the University of Michigan and a B.A. with distinction from Smith College.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: She is married to Richard Bloch and is the proud mother of two children, Rebecca and Michael, both of whom are public defenders.
Name: Susan Low Bloch

Value: M. Gregg Bloche, M.D., J.D., is Professor of Law at Georgetown University and author of The Hippocratic Myth: Why Doctors Are Under Pressure to Ration Care, Practice Politics, and Compromise Their Promise to Heal.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: He is a nationally and internationally recognized expert on health law and policy.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: Bloche’s writing has appeared in a wide range of venues, including the New England Journal of Medicine, Health Affairs and the Journal of the American Medical Association; leading law reviews; and the New York Times, Washington Post, & other media outlets.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: He has also been a frequent commentator in national broadcast media.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: He was a health care advisor to President Obama’s 2008 campaign, as well as the presidential transition, and he spoke frequently for the campaign as a “surrogate.”
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: Bloche has held teaching and research appointments at the University of Chicago, UCLA, and Columbia law schools, as well as the Brookings Institution, and the Harvard School of Public Health.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: He is a graduate of the law and medical schools at Yale, and he completed a residency in psychiatry at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: His awards and honors include a Guggenheim Fellowship and a Robert Wood Johnson Investigator Award in Health Policy Research.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: Bloche serves on several editorial boards and has advised governments and non-profits in the U.S. and abroad on a wide range of health policy issues.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: He lives in Washington, D.C.
Name: M. Gregg Bloche

Value: Professor Bonneau was an attorney at Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP, in its Manhattan office, and subsequently a partner at Hancock & Estabrook, LLP.
Name: Sonya G. Bonneau

Value: Her practice areas included appellate practice and procedure, commercial litigation, employment discrimination, and antitrust law.
Name: Sonya G. Bonneau

Value: Professor Bonneau was a law clerk for Hon. Norman A. Mordue at the United States District Court of the Northern District of New York.
Name: Sonya G. Bonneau

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, Professor Bonneau was a legal writing professor at the Syracuse University College of Law.
Name: Sonya G. Bonneau

Value: Rosa Brooks teaches courses on international law, national security, constitutional law and criminal justice.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: She joined the Law Center faculty in 2007, after serving as an associate professor at the University of Virginia School of Law. From 2016-2018, Brooks served at the Law Center’s Associate Dean for Graduate Programs.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks is also an Adjunct Senior Scholar at West Point’s Modern War Institute and a Senior Fellow at New America.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks has combined teaching and scholarship with stints in government service and a successful career in journalism.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: From 2009-2011, Brooks served as Counselor to Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Michele Flournoy and founded the Defense Department’s Office for Rule of Law and International Humanitarian Policy.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: In July 2011, she received the Secretary of Defense Medal for Outstanding Public Service.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: From 1999-2000, she served as a senior advisor at the US Department of State.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks previously wrote weekly opinion columns for Foreign Policy and the Los Angeles Times, and her articles and essays have appeared in the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Washington Post and dozens of other national and international publications.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Her most recent book, How Everything Became War and the Military Became Everything, was a New York Times Notable Book of 2016; it was shortlisted for the Lionel Gelber Prize and named one of the five best books of the year by the Council on Foreign Relations.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks is also the author of Can Might Make Rights?
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: The Rule of Law After Military Interventions (with Jane Stromseth and David Wippman), published in 2006, and A Garden of Paper Flowers (Picador, 1994).
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: In 2006-2007, Brooks was Special Counsel to the President at the Open Society Institute in New York.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks has also served as a consultant for Human Rights Watch, a fellow at the Carr Center at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, a board member of Amnesty International USA, a Term Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a lecturer at Yale Law School, a member of the Executive Council of the American Society of International Law and a member of the World Economic Forum’s Global Agenda Council on Fragile States.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: She currently serves on the advisory board of the Open Society Foundation’s US Programs, the advisory board of National Security Action and the board of the Harper’s Magazine Foundation.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Brooks received her A.B. from Harvard in history and literature, followed by a master’s degree from Oxford in social anthropology and a law degree from Yale.
Name: Rosa Brooks

Value: Chris Brummer is a Georgetown law professor and author.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: He also lectures widely on financial inclusion and equity, financial regulation and global governance.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: His views regularly inform a wide array of conversations, from diversity in regulatory agencies and corporate boards to cutting edge issues in financial technology and international regulatory and monetary diplomacy.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: His work has been featured in The New York Times, CNN, Marketwatch, Fast Company, The Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, Yahoo Money, Roll Call, Cointelegraph, and Coin Desk, among others.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Chris started his career at Cravath Swaine and Moore LLP, and now serves as the Faculty Director of the Institute of International Economic Law.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: For more than a decade, he has lent his expertise to industry leaders, nonprofits and policymakers, and offered his insights as to how firms and governments can best understand and react to new developments and challenges in the financial system.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Aside from working as a professor and spearheading multiple initiatives related to financial regulation, he also served as both a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission’s Subcommittee on Virtual Currencies and the Consultative Working Group for the European Securities and Markets Authority’s Financial Innovation Standing Committee.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Chris also concluded a three-year term as a member of the National Adjudicatory Council of FINRA.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Chris served most recently as a member of the Biden-Harris Transition team, assisting in leading work streams relating to financial technology, racial equity and systemic risk for the Treasury ART.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Chris holds multiple degrees, including a J.D. with honors from Columbia Law School and a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: He is also the author or editor of several books, including Soft Law and the Global Financial System, Minilateralism, Cryptoassets: Legal, Regulatory and Monetary Perspectives, and Fintech Law in a Nutshell.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Chris is the host of CQ Roll Call’s Fintech Beat podcast, and founder of Washington DC’s Fintech Week, an annual free event for the public.
Name: Chris Brummer

Value: Paul Butler is the Albert Brick Professor in Law at Georgetown University Law Center and a legal analyst on MSNBC.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: During the 2017-18 academic year he was the Bennett Boskey Visiting Professor at Harvard Law School.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: He holds an honorary Doctor of Law Degree from City University of New York.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Professor Butler is one of the nation’s most frequently consulted scholars on issues of race and criminal justice.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: His work has been profiled on 60 Minutes, Nightline, and The ABC, CBS and NBC Evening News.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: He lectures regularly for the American Bar Association and the NAACP, and at colleges, law schools, and community organizations throughout the United States.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: He serves on the District of Columbia Code Revision Commission as an appointee of the D.C. City Council.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Professor Butler’s scholarship has been published in many leading scholarly journals, including the Georgetown Law Journal, Yale Law Journal, Harvard Law Review, Stanford Law Review and the UCLA Law Review.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: He was named the Professor of the Year award three times by the GW graduating class.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: He was elected to the American Law Institute in 2003.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Professor Butler’s book “Let’s Get Free: A Hip-Hop Theory of Justice” received the Harry Chapin Media award.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: His book “Chokehold: Policing Black Men” was published in July 2017.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: The Washington Post named it one of the 50 best non-fiction books of 2017.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Chokehold was also named one of the best books of the year by Kirkus Reviews and the Atlanta Journal Constitution.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: The New York Times described Chokehold as the best book on criminal justice reform since The New Jim Crow.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: It was a finalist for the 2018 NAACP Image Award for best non-fiction.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Professor Butler served as a federal prosecutor with the U.S. Department of Justice, where his specialty was public corruption.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: His prosecutions included a United States Senator, three FBI agents, and several other law enforcement officials.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: Professor Butler is a graduate of Yale University and Harvard Law School.
Name: Paul Butler

Value: William W. Buzbee holds the inaugural Edward and Carole Walter Professor chair and is a Professor of Law at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He also serves as the Faculty Director of Georgetown Law’s Environmental Law & Policy Program.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: In his teaching and scholarship, he specializes in environmental law, legislation and regulation, and administrative law.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Recent publications focus on climate regulation, deregulation and law governing agency policy change, and federalism.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He also offers seminars on advanced environmental, regulatory, and constitutional law subjects, with his most recent seminar focused on “The Art of Regulatory War.”
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Buzbee’s books include the recently published Fighting Westway: Environmental Law, Citizen Activism, and the Regulatory War that Transformed New York City (Cornell University Press 2014) and Preemption Choice: The Theory, Law and Reality of Federalism’s Core Question (Cambridge University Press, hardcover 2009, paperback 2011) (William W. Buzbee editor and contributor).
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He has been a co-author of the 5th , 6th, 7th and 8th editions of Environmental Protection: Law and Policy (Aspen/Wolters Kluwer).
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Law review scholarship includes publications in New York University Law Review, University of Pennsylvania Law Review, Michigan Law Review, Stanford Law Review (co-authored), Cornell Law Review (co-authored), Duke Law Journal, George Washington Law Review, Iowa Law Review, Wisconsin Law Review, The Journal of Law and Politics and in an array of other journals, books, news outlets, and blogs.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Three of his articles have been named among the 10 best environmental or land use law articles of that year and republished in the Land Use and Environment Law Review.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He regularly assists with appellate and Supreme Court environmental, federalism, and regulatory litigation, and also has testified before congressional committees on environmental and regulatory matters.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He has published op-eds on regulatory and environmental issues with The New York Times, The Hill, CNN, and been quoted and interviewed by numerous press and media outlets.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Buzbee joined Georgetown from Emory Law School, where he was a professor of law and directed its Environmental and Natural Resources Law Program.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He also spearheaded the creation of Emory’s Turner Environmental Law Clinic and later served as the Advisory Board Chair.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He also co-directed Emory’s Center on Federalism and Intersystemic Governance.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He has been a visiting professor of law at Columbia, Cornell and Illinois law schools.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: He has also served as a professor for the Leiden-Amsterdam-Columbia Law School Summer Program in American Law.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Buzbee is a founding Member Scholar of the Center for Progressive Reform, a Washington D.C.-based regulatory think tank.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Buzbee was awarded the 2007-2008 Emory Williams Teaching Award for excellence in teaching.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Buzbee clerked for United States Judge Jose A. Cabranes, and before becoming a professor was an attorney-fellow at the Natural Resources Defense Council, and did environmental, land use and litigation work for the New York City law firm, Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: JD, Columbia Law School, 1986; BA, Amherst College, magna cum laude, 1983.
Name: William W. Buzbee

Value: Professor Byrne joined the Law Center faculty in 1985.
Name: J. Peter Byrne

Value: After graduation from the University of Virginia law school, he served as a law clerk to Judge Frank Coffin and U.S. Supreme Court Justice Lewis Powell and then worked as an associate with the D.C. firm of Covington & Burling.
Name: J. Peter Byrne

Value: He teaches and writes in the areas of Property, Land Use, Constitutional Law, and Higher Education Law and Policy.
Name: J. Peter Byrne

Value: He served as Associate Dean for the JD Program from 1997 to 2000.
Name: J. Peter Byrne

Value: He was John Carroll Research Professor in 1996-97.
Name: J. Peter Byrne

Value: Rachel Camp is a Co-Director of the Domestic Violence Clinic and a Professor from Practice at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: She joined Georgetown’s faculty in 2011 and became a co-director of the Domestic Violence Clinic (DVC) in 2013.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: Professor Camp has devoted her career to advocating on behalf of vulnerable and marginalized populations.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: She has represented, and has supervised law students representing, hundreds of survivors of intimate partner violence in civil protection order and family law cases during her time at Georgetown and while a Clinical Teaching Fellow at the University of Baltimore School of Law.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: In addition to direct legal representation, Professor Camp has supervised law students on a variety of community education and systemic legal reform projects aimed at increasing access to justice for survivors.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: Professor Camp’s co-authored article on integrating community legal education into clinical programs was published in the Clinical Law Review in 2012.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: Between 2000-2008, Professor Camp served as an Assistant Attorney General with the Oregon Department of Justice.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: While there, she served as counsel for a variety of state agencies, including the Department of Human Services in matters involving child abuse and neglect.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: Prior to her employment at the Oregon Department of Justice, Professor Camp was an attorney at the Maryland Disability Law Center representing patients at a maximum-security state psychiatric hospital in civil and administrative matters.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: Professor Camp currently serves on the Board of Directors of the D.C. Affordable Law Firm and Girls on the Run of Central Maryland.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: In addition to other law review articles and publications, in Coercing Pregnancy, 21 WM.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: & MARY J. WOMEN & L. 275 (2015), Professor Camp examined the intersection between intimate partner violence (IPV), reproductive coercion, and pregnancy.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: In her most recent article, Pursuing Accountability for Perpetrators of Intimate Partner Violence: The Peril (an Utility?) of Shame, 98 BOSTON UNIV. L. REV. 1677 (2018), Professor Camp explores how formal and informal methods of shaming perpetrators of IPV lead to counterproductive outcomes for reducing violence in intimate relationships and increased risk of harm for survivors.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: In addition to her work in the DVC, Professor Camp directs the LL.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: M. program for the D.C. Affordable Law Firm, a program that allows recent law graduates to provide civil legal representation to D.C. residents who fall between 200-400% above the federal poverty rate and who otherwise may be unable to obtain legal representation.
Name: A. Rachel Camp

Value: In 2016, Yael Cannon co-founded, with Professor Vicki Girard, the Georgetown University Health Justice Alliance, an academic Medical-Legal Partnership training the next generation of health, law, and policy leaders to work together in pursuit of health justice as they serve some of the most vulnerable members of our D.C. community.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Professor Cannon serves as the Legal Director of this cross-campus collaborative and also serves as Director of the Health Justice Alliance’s Law Clinic, which brings together students and professionals in law and health to provide holistic civil legal advocacy to address the social determinants of health for patients living in poverty in Washington D.C.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: The law clinic embeds students in MedStar Georgetown Community Pediatrics health clinics at a homeless family shelter, a high school health center, and a pediatric mobile van, where patients are screened for unmet legal needs.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Law students partner with healthcare providers and students to advance their casework.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Georgetown University medical students participate in a one month rotation within the law clinic, which provides intensive learning and advocacy collaboration opportunities across disciplines.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Professor Cannon also works closely with cross-campus research partners to develop and implement assessment tools to evaluate the impact of the Health Justice Alliance’s service and academic initiatives on learners, patients, clients and health providers.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: In its first year, the Health Justice Alliance team was recognized by Georgetown University and the Fox 5 Morning News as “Campus Heroes” for its work serving families in need in Washington, D.C.  Professor Cannon previously taught clinical poverty law courses and doctrinal courses at the University of New Mexico School of Law, where she was an Associate Professor.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: She led a successful effort there to secure a $2.6 million grant from the W.K. Kellogg Foundation to develop a new law school initiative, the Center for Child and Family Justice, which prepares and mobilizes law students and graduates to pursue justice, equity, and health for New Mexico’s most vulnerable families.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: While in New Mexico, Professor Cannon co-chaired the state legislature’s John Paul Taylor Early Childhood Taskforce and served by appointment on the New Mexico Supreme Court’s Children’s Court Rules Committee.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Professor Cannon began her law teaching career at the American University Washington College of Law, where she served as a Practitioner-in-Residence and Acting Director of the Disability Rights Law Clinic and taught doctrinal courses.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Prior to teaching, Professor Cannon was an attorney at the Children’s Law Center’s medical-legal partnership providing legal services at Washington, D.C. pediatric clinics and engaging in policy advocacy on behalf of low-income children and families.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: She is a co-author of the textbook Special Education Advocacy, the treatise AIDS and the Law, and articles in law journals and other periodicals, including a study conducted with the New Mexico Sentencing Commission of trauma among youth in the state’s juvenile justice system.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Her research focuses on the ways in which the law can address social determinants of health to ensure better outcomes for children and families living in poverty.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Professor Cannon graduated with distinction from Stanford Law School and summa cum laude from the University of Maryland with B.A. degrees in History and African American Studies.
Name: Yael Zakai Cannon

Value: Professor Carroll teaches courses on legal analysis and communication as well as technology and the press.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: Her scholarship focuses on the dramatic changes to the press in the past several decades and how law should respond to them.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: It is informed by her work as a journalist before becoming a lawyer.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: She has written about transparency laws and newsgathering, privacy and the meaning of newsworthiness, and the First Amendment and methods of protecting watchdog journalism.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, Professor Carroll was a litigator at Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman in California.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: She was also an adjunct professor at University of the Pacific, McGeorge School of Law.
Name: Erin Carroll

Value: Sheryll Cashin is an author and the Carmack Waterhouse Professor of Law, Civil Rights and Social Justice at Georgetown University.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Currently she teaches Constitutional Law, Race and American Law, and a writing seminar about American segregation, education and opportunity.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Her new book — White Space, Black ‘Hood: Opportunity Hoarding and Segregation in the Age of Inequality (forthcoming, Beacon 2021) — is about the role of residential segregation in producing racial inequality.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Her book, Loving: Interracial Intimacy in America and the Threat to White Supremacy (Beacon, 2017), explores the history and future of interracial intimacy, how white supremacy was constructed and how “culturally dexterous” allies undermine it.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Her book, Place Not Race (Beacon, 2014), recommended radical reforms of selective college admissions in order to promote robust diversity; it was nominated for an NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Non-Fiction in 2015.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Her book, The Failures of Integration (PublicAffairs, 2004) explored the persistence and consequences of race and class segregation.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: It was an Editors’ Choice in the New York Times Book Review.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Cashin is also a three-time nominee for the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award for non-fiction (2005, 2009, and 2018).
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She has published widely in academic journals and written commentaries for Politico Magazine, the New York Times, Los Angeles Times, Washington Post, Salon, The Root, and other media.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Professor Cashin serves as board member of the Poverty and Race Research Action Council.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She is former Vice Chair of the board of Building One America, a network of local, multiracial coalitions that promote social inclusion, racial justice and sustainable economic opportunity, especially in distressed places.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She served for a decade on the trustee boards of Vanderbilt University, The Duke Ellington School of the Arts, and the National Portrait Gallery.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She worked in the Clinton White House as an advisor on urban and economic policy, particularly concerning community development in inner-city neighborhoods.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Cashin is frequently asked to speak to academic and policy audiences as well as at book events for people who engage with her as an author.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She has delivered keynote or endowed lectures at twenty universities.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: For her two decades of writing and advocacy for residential and school integration, the Fair Housing Justice Center honored her with the 2017 Acting for Justice Award for Outstanding Contributions to Civil Rights.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Professor Cashin was law clerk to U.S. Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall and Judge Abner Mikva of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She graduated summa cum laude from Vanderbilt University with a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: As a Marshall Scholar, she received a masters in English Law with honors from Oxford University and received a J.D. with honors from Harvard Law School, where she was a member of the Harvard Law Review.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Cashin was born and raised in Huntsville, Alabama, where her parents were political activists.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: She lives in Washington with her husband and twin boys.
Name: Sheryll D. Cashin

Value: Professor Michael J. Cedrone’s teaching and scholarship are rooted in the belief that professional identity is formed when law students must reason, act, and reflect as lawyers do.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: In his first year Legal Practice course, students learn to research, analyze, and advocate orally and in writing through rich simulations involving complex facts and law.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: In his innovative Week One class, students represent clients dealing with a possible Foreign Corrupt Practices
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Act violation that comes to light during an international corporate acquisition.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Students gather facts through interviewing a witness, report to the General Counsel of their corporate client (a role played by many of Georgetown’s most prominent alums), and renegotiate terms of the deal to account for the risks of an FCPA prosecution.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Finally, he teaches the Intro to United States Legal Systems course in Georgetown’s LLM program.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Cedrone has explored the formation of young lawyers’ professional identity in his law review article, The Developmental Path of the Lawyer, and he has frequently presented on these topics for the Legal Writing Institute and the Association of Legal Writing Directors.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: He lectures for Themis Bar Review and the International Law Institute, and he has conducted writing workshops for federal employees.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Professor Cedrone joined the Georgetown Law faculty in 2008 following a federal District Court clerkship and four years of practice at the Boston firm Peabody &Arnold, LLP.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: From 2005-07, he taught legal research and writing as an adjunct professor at Boston University School of Law and served as pro bono counsel for the Massachusetts Board of Bar Examiners, grading Massachusetts Bar Exam and representing the Board at a character and fitness hearing for an applicant to the Massachusetts bar.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: He is a magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law and Harvard College.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Prior to law school, Cedrone taught for five years in the Massachusetts public schools and earned a master’s degree in education from Boston University.
Name: Michael J. Cedrone

Value: Josh Chafetz received his B.A. from Yale University, his doctorate in Politics from Oxford (where he studied as a Rhodes Scholar), and his J.D. from Yale Law School.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: Following law school, he clerked for Judge Guido Calabresi of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, he spent twelve years on the faculty at Cornell Law School.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: His research interests include structural constitutional law, American and British constitutional history, legislation and legislative procedure, American political development, and the intersection of law and politics.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: His second book, Congress’s Constitution: Legislative Authority and the Separation of Powers, was published by Yale University Press in 2017.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: He is also the author of Democracy’s Privileged Few: Legislative Privilege and Democratic Norms in the British and American Constitutions (Yale University Press, 2007) and is a co-editor (along with William N. Eskridge, Jr., Elizabeth Garrett, and James Brudney) of the leading casebook in Legislation, Cases and Materials on Legislation and Regulation: Statutes and the Creation of Public Policy, published by West.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: His scholarship has been published in the Harvard Law Review, Yale Law Journal, University of Chicago Law Review, University of Pennsylvania Law Review, Duke Law Journal, Notre Dame Law Review, and Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities, among others.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: He has also written for a number of popular press outlets, including the New York Times, Washington Post, Politico, Slate, and The New Republic.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: In 2019-2020, he served as a member of the American Political Science Association Presidential Task Force on Congressional Reform.
Name: Josh Chafetz

Value: Professor Chander is an expert on the global regulation of new technologies.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: A graduate of Harvard College and Yale Law School, he clerked for Chief Judge Jon O. Newman of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals and Judge William A. Norris of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: He practiced law in New York and Hong Kong with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: He has been a visiting law professor at Yale, the University of Chicago, Stanford, Cornell, and Tsinghua.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: He previously served as the Director of the California International Law Center and Martin Luther King, Jr. Professor of Law at UC Davis.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: A member of the American Law Institute, he has also served on the Executive Council of the American Society of International Law, where he co-founded the International Law and Technology Interest Group.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: The author of The Electronic Silk Road (Yale University Press), he serves as a judge of the Stanford Junior International Faculty Forum.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: A recipient of Google Research Awards and an Andrew Mellon grant on the topic of surveillance, he has served on ICTSD/World Economic Forum expert groups on the digital economy.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: He serves as an Adjunct Senior Research Scholar at Columbia University’s School of International and Public Policy, a faculty advisor to Georgetown’s Institute for Technology Law and Policy, and as a faculty affiliate of Yale’s Information Society Project.
Name: Anupam Chander

Value: Professor Cohen teaches and writes about surveillance, privacy and data protection, intellectual property, information platforms, and the ways that networked information and communication technologies are reshaping legal institutions.
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: She is the author of Between Truth and Power: The Legal Constructions of Informational Capitalism (Oxford University Press, 2019), Configuring the Networked Self: Law, Code, and the Play of Everyday Practice (Yale University Press, 2012), and numerous articles and book chapters, and she is a co-author of Copyright in a Global Information Economy (Wolters Kluwer, 5th ed. 2020).
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: She is a faculty co-director of the Institute for Technology Law and Policy, a faculty co-director of the Center on Privacy and Technology, and a member of the Advisory Board of the Electronic Privacy Information Center.
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: Prior to joining the Law Center faculty in 1999, Professor Cohen was Assistant Professor of Law at the University of Pittsburgh School of Law.
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: She previously practiced with the San Francisco firm of McCutchen, Doyle, Brown & Enersen, where she specialized in intellectual property litigation.
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: She was law clerk to Judge Stephen Reinhardt of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Name: Julie Cohen

Value: David
Name: David D. Cole

Value: Cole teaches constitutional law, national security, and criminal justice at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He is also the legal affairs correspondent for The Nation, and a regular contributor to the New York Review of Books.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He has been published widely in law journals and the popular press, including the Yale Law Journal, California Law Review, Stanford Law Review, New York Times, Washington Post, The New Republic, Wall Street Journal, and Los Angeles Times.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He is the author of seven books.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: Less Safe, Less Free: Why America Is Losing the War on Terror, published in 2007, and co-authored with Jules Lobel, won the Palmer Civil Liberties Prize for best book on national security and civil liberties.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: Enemy Aliens: Double Standards and Constitutional Freedoms in the War on Terrorism, received the American Book Award in 2004.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: No Equal Justice: Race and Class in the American Criminal Justice System was named Best Non-Fiction Book of 1999 by the Boston Book Review, and best book on an issue of national policy in 1999 by the American Political Science Association.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: His most recent book is The Torture Memos: Rationalizing the Unthinkable (2009).
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He received his bachelor’s degree and law degree from Yale University.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He worked as a staff attorney for the Center for Constitutional Rights from 1985-90, and has continued to litigate as a professor.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He has litigated many significant constitutional cases in the Supreme Court, including Texas v. Johnson and United States v. Eichman, which extended First Amendment protection to flagburning; National Endowment for the Arts v. Finley, which challenged political content restriction on NEA funding; and Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project, which challenged the constitutionality of the statute prohibiting “material support” to terrorist groups, which makes speech advocating peace and human rights a crime.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: He has been involved in many of the nation’s most important cases involving civil liberties and national security, including the case of Maher Arar, a Canadian citizen rendered to Syria by U.S. officials and tortured there.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: The late New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis called David “one of the country’s great legal voices for civil liberties today,” and Nat Hentoff has called him “a one-man Committee of Correspondence in the tradition of patriot Sam Adams.”
Name: David D. Cole

Value: David has received two honorary degrees, and numerous awards for his human rights work, including, in 2013, the inaugural Norman Dorsen Presidential Prize from the ACLU for lifetime commitment to civil liberties.
Name: David D. Cole

Value: A magna cum laude graduate of Princeton University’s Woodrow Wilson School of International and Public Policy, Professor Cook graduated from the Yale Law School and practiced venture capital and corporate law.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: He has completed two post-graduate fellowships, the first in Ethics and the Professions at the Kennedy School of Government and the second in Religion and Public Values at the Harvard Divinity School.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: He teaches interrelated courses on race and class stratification, with a particular emphasis on progressive politics, voting rights, elections, and the legal structure of the political process.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: He has pioneered a groundbreaking course – Race, Inequality and Progressive Politics: Voting Rights in America – that brings professional, graduate, and undergraduate students from various disciplines into the same classroom to grapple with issues facing U.S. democracy.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: At the local level, he works as a community practitioner, building bridges between the university and underserved populations, offering practicums on entrepreneurship and social innovation, global cities & urbanization, and community development.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: These courses provide students with a unique opportunity to partner with underserved communities in finding solutions to the complex problems they face.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: Professor Cook’s scholarship has explored the relationship between progressive religious theology and progressive politics in America.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: His book, The Least of These: Race, Law and Religion in American Culture, explores the relevance of the social gospel and Dr. Martin Luther King’s conception of the Beloved Community for race, class and cultural divides in American Society.
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: For his work as a scholar and community activist who has worked with various grassroots and faith-based initiatives on community empowerment and economic development projects, the American Bar Association honored Professor Cook as One of 21 Lawyers Leading America into the 21st Century, citing his “unique synergy of action and thought.”
Name: Anthony E. Cook

Value: Professor Copacino is Director of the Criminal Justice Clinic and the E. Barrett Prettyman graduate fellowship in criminal trial advocacy.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: Prior to joining the faculty, he was the Director of the Juvenile Law Clinic at the Antioch School of Law.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: He is a graduate of the University of Virginia Law School and received an LL.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: M. as a Prettyman Fellow at the Law Center.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: He has served as lead counsel in hundreds of criminal cases and post conviction cases in the District of Columbia.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: He regularly participates in local and national training programs for criminal defense lawyers.
Name: John M. Copacino

Value: Nakita Cuttino’s primary research interests are in the areas of banking regulations, consumer finance, and securities law.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Her research focuses on the efficacy of and risks related to the emerging markets of fintech services, cryptocurrencies, and more generally the use of artificial intelligence in the financial sector.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Her work seeks to assess whether these emerging markets reasonably fit within existing regulatory schemes or if such schemes should be reassessed to better serve the modernization of financial services and democratization of wealth in the United States.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Prior to joining the Georgetown Law faculty, Professor Cuttino was an Assistant Professor of Law at Duke University Law School.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Prior to that, she practiced as a corporate associate with Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP in the Houston and New York offices, specializing in complex debt finance transactions with lending commitments ranging from $200 million to $1.5 billion as well as public and private security offerings with gross proceeds ranging from $300 million to $1.5 billion.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Prior to joining Simpson, she served as a law clerk to Judge Eric L. Clay of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Cuttino graduated from Duke University School of Law in 2012 and earned her B.B.A., magna cum laude, from Howard University in 2008.
Name: Nakita Cuttino

Value: Professor De Amicis is the faculty co-director of the Center on Transnational Business and the Law and the faculty director of the Executive Securities and Financial Regulation LL.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: M. program.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: He joined the faculty on a full-time basis in 2019 following a career as a partner at Ropes & Gray LLP, an international law firm, and as the Vice President and General Counsel of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (now the Development Finance Corporation), the U.S. government’s bilateral development finance institution.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: He has taught comparative law at the University of Arizona Law School, lectured at numerous foreign law schools, including Leiden University and the National Law University, Delhi, India, been a Fellow at the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in the Humanities and Social Sciences, and served as the Executive Director of the National Law Center for Inter-American Free Trade, a commercial law reform institute.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: Professor De Amicis is an external member of sanctions committees of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Inter-American Development Bank that hear appeals of administrative decisions sanctioning parties for fraudulent, corrupt or collusive practices.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: His activities in the field of impact investing include serving on a board of directors of a corporation that supports microfinance institutions operating internationally through financial products that hedge local currency risk.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: Long been active in the American Bar Association, where he chaired the ABA Section of International Law, Professor De Amicis is involved in the ABA’s international rule of law programs, currently serving on the ABA’s Middle East and North Africa Council.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: He also participates in commercial law reform projects in foreign countries as an expert for the Commercial Law Development Program of the U.S. Commerce Department.
Name: Don S. De Amicis

Value: For more than a decade, Professor DeLaurentis was a litigator whose practice involved civil and white-collar litigation before local and federal courts throughout the United States and the Commonwealth of Puerto as well as internal corporate investigations of major nonprofit organizations.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: She was a partner at the firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson and Hand where she also served as co-chair of the firm’s Summer Associate Program, a member of the firm’s Hiring Committee, and as the firm’s Sexual Harassment Ombudsman.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: Prior to joining the Law Center, Professor DeLaurentis was an instructor of the Lawyering Skills Program at The Catholic University of America, Columbus School of Law.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: At the Law Center, Professor DeLaurentis served for five years as chair of the legal writing program and has been director of the Law Center’s Writing Center since 2007.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: She also has developed a collaboration with the Archdiocese of Washington Catholic Charities Legal Network in which her first year students work on pro bono projects that assist the Legal Network and for which she was awarded the 2015 John Carroll Society’s Pro Bono Legal Service Award.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: She received the Frank F. Flegal Excellence in Teaching Award in 2020.
Name: Frances C. DeLaurentis

Value: Mary B. DeRosa served as Deputy Assistant and Deputy Counsel to the President, and as National Security Council Legal Adviser in the Obama Administration.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: After leaving the White House in the Summer of 2011, she served as Alternate Representative of the United States to the 66th Session of the UN General Assembly, an Ambassador-level position with the US Mission to the United Nations.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: Prior to joining the Obama Administration in 2009, Ms. DeRosa was Chief Counsel for National Security for the Senate Judiciary Committee, working for the Chairman, Senator Patrick Leahy.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: She has also been a Senior Fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, served on the staff of the Clinton Administration National Security Council as Legal Adviser and Deputy Legal Adviser, and was Special Counsel to the General Counsel at the Department of Defense.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: Before joining the government, Ms. DeRosa was in private practice at Arnold & Porter.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: She served as a law clerk to the Honorable Richard Cardamone, United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: Mary B. DeRosa

Value: Professor Diamond has previously taught at American University’s Washington College of Law, the Antioch School of Law, Gonzaga University School of Law, and the University of Puerto Rico School of Law.
Name: Michael R. Diamond

Value: He has served as a consultant for the American Bar Association, Central and Eastern European Law Initiative, on proposed laws concerning housing in Russia and Bosnia and as a legal education specialist on a team conducting a mid-term evaluation of the U.S. Agency for International Development’s Economic Law and Improved Procurement Systems project in Indonesia.
Name: Michael R. Diamond

Value: He has authored a text on real property, a casebook in corporations as well as  numerous articles, primarily in the area of poverty, community lawyering and property.
Name: Michael R. Diamond

Value: In addition, he has published several books in the area of business law.
Name: Michael R. Diamond

Value: Areas of expertise: Housing and economic development; property; contracts; corporations.
Name: Michael R. Diamond

Value: Professor Donahoe attended Georgetown Law, where she graduated magna cum laude and was an editor on The Georgetown Law Journal.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: She served as a law clerk for Judge George H. Revercomb of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: After clerking, she decided to pursue a career in criminal defense, representing the indigent in Superior Court.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: As a Prettyman Fellow in the Georgetown Criminal Justice Clinic, she supervised law students in court, where she discovered her passion for teaching.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: Professor Donahoe has been teaching courses in legal research, analysis, writing, and practice since 1993.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: She was the first rotating chair of the legal practice program and has served as chair of the Legal Writing Committee.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: She has been instrumental in helping to expand and improve the legal writing program at Georgetown.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: She is known for her innovative teaching using technology and her expertise in writing pedagogy.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: In 2008, Professor Donahoe was awarded the Georgetown Frank Flegal Award for Excellence in Teaching.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: Professor Donahoe is the author and creator of TeachingLaw.com, an interactive, online case book, which is used across the country in legal research and writing courses to more actively engage students in the classroom and to provide innovative teachers with a platform for teaching digital-age students.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: She is also a co-author of a legal writing pedagogy book, Legal Writing Pedagogy: Comments, Conferences, and Classroom Teaching.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: In addition to her scholarship on pedagogy, Professor Donahoe’s law review articles focus on Fourth Amendment search and seizure law with topics ranging from the unconstitutionality of strip searches and DNA searches to the implicit bias pervasive in consent searches.
Name: Diana Roberto Donahoe

Value: Laura K. Donohue is a Professor of Law at Georgetown Law, Director of Georgetown’s Center on National Security and the Law, and Director of the Center on Privacy and Technology.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: She writes on political theory, public law, constitutional law, federal courts, national security, and legal history.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: Her work on new and emerging technologies centers on social media, biometric identification, augmented and virtual reality, artificial intelligence, and drones.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: Her book, The Future of Foreign Intelligence: Privacy and Surveillance in a Digital Age (Oxford University Press, 2016), won the 2016 IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law/Roy C. Palmer Civil Liberties Prize.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: She also wrote The Cost of Counterterrorism: Power, Politics, and Liberty (Cambridge University Press, 2008); and Counterterrorist Law and Emergency Law in the United Kingdom 1922-2000 (Irish Academic Press, 2007).
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: Professor Donohue’s articles have been published by the California Law Review, Stanford Law Review, Supreme Court Review, University of Chicago Law Review, University of Pennsylvania Law Review, Yale Law Journal Online, Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy, Harvard National Security Journal, and numerous other scholarly journals.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: In November 2015, the U.S. Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court appointed her as one of five amici curiae under the 2015 USA FREEDOM Act. Professor Donohue is a Life Member of the Council on Foreign Relations; an Advisory Board Member of the Electronic Privacy Information Center; and Reporter for the American Bar Association’s Criminal Justice Section Task Force on Border Searches of Electronic Devices.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: She has served on the Board of the American Bar Association’s Standing Committee on Law and National Security and is a Senior Scholar at Georgetown Law’s Center for the Constitution.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: Donohue obtained her AB in Philosophy (with Honors) from Dartmouth College; her MA in Peace Studies (with Distinction) from the University of Ulster, Northern Ireland; her JD (with Distinction) from Stanford Law School; and her PhD in History from the University of Cambridge, England.
Name: Laura Donohue

Value: Peter Edelman is the Carmack Waterhouse Professor of Law and Public Policy at Georgetown University Law Center, where he teaches constitutional law and poverty law and is faculty director of the Georgetown Center on Poverty and Inequality.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: On the faculty since 1982, he has also served in all three branches of government.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: During President Clinton’s first term he was Counselor to HHS Secretary Donna Shalala and then Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: Professor Edelman has been Associate Dean of the Law Center, Director of the New York State Division for Youth, and Vice President of the University of Massachusetts.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He was a Legislative Assistant to Senator Robert F. Kennedy and was Issues Director for Senator Edward Kennedy’s Presidential campaign in 1980.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: Earlier, he was a Law Clerk to Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg and before that to Judge Henry J. Friendly on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He also worked in the U.S. Department of Justice as Special Assistant to Assistant Attorney General John Douglas.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: Professor Edelman’s recent book, Not a Crime to Be Poor: The Criminalization of Poverty in America, was published by The New Press in 2017.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He previously wrote So Rich So Poor: Why It’s So Hard To End Poverty in America which was also published by The New Press in 2012.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: And before that he wrote Searching for America’s Heart: RFK and the Renewal of Hope, which was published by Houghton-Mifflin in 2001.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He also co-authored Reconnecting Disadvantaged Young Men, which was published by the Urban Institute in 2006, and is the author of many articles on poverty, constitutional law, and issues about children and youth.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: His article in the Atlantic Monthly, entitled “The Worst Thing Bill Clinton Has Done,” received the Harry Chapin Media Award.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: Peter Edelman is currently chair of the District of Columbia Access to Justice Commission, and formerly board chair of the National Center for Youth, the American Constitution Society for Law and Policy, and the Public Welfare Foundation, board president emeritus of the New Israel Fund, and a board member of the Center for Law and Social Policy, the Center for American Progress Action Fund, and a half dozen other nonprofit organizations.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He has been a United States-Japan Leadership Program Fellow, was the J. Skelly Wright Memorial Fellow at Yale Law School, and has received numerous honors and awards for his work.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: He grew up in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Name: Peter B. Edelman

Value: Professor Epstein has directed the Domestic Violence Clinic since 1993.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: She has been the Director of the Georgetown University Law Center’s Domestic Violence Clinic for more than 25 years, and served as Associate Dean for Experiential Learning from 2005-2012.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: She has spent decades advocating for the rights of survivors of domestic violence and has represented hundreds of women in civil protection order cases.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: She co-chaired the design and implementation of the DC Superior Court’s Domestic Violence Division, an early, model effort to restructure the way civil and criminal family abuse cases are handled.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: For five years, she served as Co-Director of the court’s Domestic Violence Intake Center.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: She served on the NFL Players’ Association Commission on Violence, and has served as Chair of the DC Domestic Violence Fatality Review Board, Director of the Emergency Domestic Relations Project, and as a member of the DC Mayor’s Commission on Violence Against Women, the DC Superior Court Domestic Violence Coordinating Council, the DC Coalition Against Domestic Violence Board of Directors, and the Board of Directors of the House of Ruth.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: Professor Epstein has trained hundreds of police officers, prosecutors, and judges around the country and internationally on domestic violence issues.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: In 2020, she was awarded the  American Bar Association’s Margaret Brent Award  for professional excellence in women lawyers.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: She serves on D.C.’s Judicial Nominations Commission, helping to select judges to serve on the local courts.
Name: Deborah Epstein

Value: Professor Ernst joined the Georgetown faculty in the 1988-89 academic year.
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: He is the author of Lawyers Against Labor (1995), for which he received the Littleton Griswold Award of the American Historical Association and co-editor of Total War and the Law (2003).
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: In 1996, he was a Fulbright Research Scholar at the National Library of New Zealand, and in 1998 he was the Jack and Margaret Sweet Visiting Professor of History at Michigan State University.
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: He was a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Fellow during the 2003-04 academic year.
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: From 2006 to 2010, he was co-editor of “Studies in Legal History,” a book series sponsored by the American Society for Legal History and the University of North Carolina Press.
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: He teaches courses in American Legal History and Property.
Name: Daniel R. Ernst

Value: Lilian V. Faulhaber teaches courses on federal income taxation, EU tax, international taxation, tax policy, and international business law.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: Her writing focuses on tax competition, tax avoidance, international taxation, charitable giving, and European Union law.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: Before joining the Georgetown faculty, Professor Faulhaber was an Advisor to the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) Project at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: Prior to her work at the OECD, she was an Associate Professor at Boston University School of Law.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: Professor Faulhaber clerked for Senior Judge Robert E. Keeton and Judge William G. Young, both on the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, and was an associate at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton LLP in New York.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: She is a graduate of Harvard College, Cambridge University, and Harvard Law School, where she was editor-in-chief of the Harvard International Law Journal.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: In 2013, Professor Faulhaber received Boston University School of Law’s Michael W. Melton Memorial Award for Teaching Excellence.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: In 2018, she received Georgetown Law’s Frank F. Flegal Excellence in Teaching Award and Georgetown Law’s Faculty Member of the Year Award.
Name: Lilian Faulhaber

Value: Professor Feinerman joined the Law Center faculty as a visiting professor for the 1985-86 academic year.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: Immediately after law school he studied in the People’s Republic of China.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: Subsequently, he joined the New York firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell as a corporate associate.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: During 1982-83, Professor Feinerman was Fulbright Lecturer on Law at Peking University.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: In 1986, he was a Fulbright researcher in Japan.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: In 1989, he was awarded a MacArthur Foundation fellowship to study China’s practice of international law.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: During the 1992-93 academic year, he was a Fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: From 1993-95, on leave from the Law Center, Professor Feinerman was the Director of the Committee on Scholarly Communication with China.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: Professor Feinerman served as Editor-in-Chief of the ABA’s China Law Reporter from 1986-1998.
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: Also, Professor Feinerman was the Co-editor of The Limits of the Rule of Law in China (2001), and Co-Author of China After the WTO:
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: What You Need to Know Now(2001).
Name: James V. Feinerman

Value: Heidi Li Feldman is Professor of Law at Georgetown University Law Center, with a courtesy appointment in the Philosophy Department at Georgetown University.
Name: Heidi Li Feldman

Value: She has written major articles on tort law and on legal ethics.
Name: Heidi Li Feldman

Value: Her scholarly expertise includes the U.S. civil justice system more generally.
Name: Heidi Li Feldman
