Value: After graduating from Cornell Law School summa cum laude, Professor O’Sullivan clerked for Chief Judge Levin Campbell of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit and then for Justice Sandra Day O’Connor of the United States Supreme Court.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: She spent five years with Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York, where she worked on mergers and acquisitions litigation as well as white-collar criminal defense matters.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Her experience at Davis Polk included work on U.S. v. REI, a lengthy and complex public corruption case, and the BCCI case, where she worked with Robert Fiske in the defense of First American Bank, Clark Clifford, and Robert Altman.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: In 1991, Professor O’Sullivan joined the Criminal Division of the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York as an Assistant United States Attorney.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: There, she spent most of her time prosecuting major white-collar crimes.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: She and another AUSA successfully prosecuted the largest bank fraud case in the country at the time and the first to be brought under the financial kingpin statute.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Professor O’Sullivan was then recruited by Robert Fiske, the newly appointed independent counsel for the Whitewater investigation, to join his staff in Little Rock, Arkansas, as associate counsel.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: She worked for Mr. Fiske, and briefly for Ken Starr, before commencing her teaching career at Georgetown in 1995.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Also in 1995, on appointment by the Supreme Court, she successfully briefed and argued a case on behalf of an indigent petitioner in a case pending before that Court.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Professor O’Sullivan has written many articles and the leading casebook on white-collar crime and is a recognized expert on both the federal sentencing guidelines and white collar criminal law.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Professor O’Sullivan is increasingly interested in the subject of cross-border criminality and law enforcement.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: With Professors David Luban and David Stewart, she published a casebook on International and Transnational Criminal Law.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: She has taught international criminal law in London and Dublin as well as Georgetown.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: In 2010, she served as a visiting professional at, and then a consultant for, the Office of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Professor O’Sullivan is a member of the American Law Institute and has served as a member of, and reporter for, such projects as the ABA’s revision of the Standards for Criminal Justice on Guilty Pleas and the U.S. Sentencing Commission’s Ad Hoc Advisory Group on the Sentencing Guidelines applicable to Organizations.
Name: Julie Rose O'Sullivan

Value: Paul Ohm is a Professor of Law at the Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: He specializes in information privacy, computer crime law, intellectual property, and criminal procedure.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: He teaches courses in all of these topics and more and he serves as a faculty director for the Center on Privacy and Technology at Georgetown.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: In his work, Professor Ohm tries to build new interdisciplinary bridges between law and computer science.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Much of his scholarship focuses on how evolving technology disrupts individual privacy.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: His article
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Broken Promises of Privacy: Responding to the Surprising Failure of Anonymization, 57 UCLA Law Review 1701, has sparked an international debate about the need to reshape dramatically the way we regulate privacy.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: He is commonly cited and quoted by news organizations including the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and NPR.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Professor
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Ohm began his academic career on the faculty of the University of Colorado Law School, where he also served as the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs and Faculty Director for the Silicon Flatirons Center.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: From 2012 to 2013, Professor Ohm served as Senior Policy Advisor to the Federal Trade Commission.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Before becoming a professor, he served as an Honors Program trial attorney in the U.S. Department of Justice’s Computer Crime and Intellectual Property Section.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Before that, he clerked for Judge Betty Fletcher of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and Judge Mariana Pfaelzer of the United States District Court for the Central District of California.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: He is a graduate of the UCLA School of Law.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Before attending law school, Professor Ohm worked for several years as a computer programmer and network systems administrator after earning undergraduate degrees in computer science and electrical engineering from Yale University.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Today he continues to write thousands of lines of python and perl code each year.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Professor
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Ohm blogs at Freedom to Tinker.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Professor
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Ohm writes at the intersection of computer science and law, attempting to bridge the two disciplines with rigor.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Current projects include: Ethical and Policy Issues in the Statistical Use of Big Data, American Statistical Association, Joint Statistical Meetings, Boston, MA, August, 2014.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: University of San Diego Center for Computation, Mathematics and the Law Inaugural Workshop, San Diego, CA, March 21-22, 2014.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Re-Identification Risk of De-Identified Data Sets in the Era of Big Data, AAAS Annual Meeting, Chicago, IL, February 16, 2014.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Workshop on the Social, Economic, and Workforce Implications of Big Data Analytics and Decision Making, NSF, Washington, DC, January 30-31, 2014.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Privacy, Information and Law, at REWIRED: How Law and Technology Shape Social Progress, Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics, University of Oregon, January 22, 2014.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Professor
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Ohm has taught courses in Criminal Procedure, Introduction to Intellectual Property, Copyright, Information Privacy, Quantitative Methods and Computer Crime.
Name: Paul Ohm

Value: Michael S. Pardo’s teaching and scholarship are in the areas of evidence, criminal procedure, civil procedure, philosophy of law, and law and neuroscience.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: His current research focuses on philosophical issues pertaining to evidence, procedure, and legal proof.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: Professor Pardo’s publications include two books and more than fifty articles, essays, and book chapters.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: His books include: An Analytical Approach to Evidence (6th edition, Wolters Kluwer, 2016, with Allen et al) and Minds, Brains, and Law (Oxford University Press, 2013, with Patterson).
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: In addition, he is a co-editor of Philosophical Foundations of Law and Neuroscience (Oxford University Press, 2016, with Patterson).
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: Professor Pardo’s articles have appeared in several distinguished journals, including the Vanderbilt, William & Mary, Boston College, Illinois, Northwestern, Texas, and Iowa Law Reviews, and in Legal Theory, Law & Philosophy, Jurisprudence, Neuroethics, Criminal Law & Philosophy, and the Journal of Legal Studies, among others.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, Professor Pardo was on the faculty at the University of Alabama School of Law, where he was the Henry Upson Sims Professor and a founder and co-director of the law school’s Program on Cross-Disciplinary Legal Studies.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: He has also served as Chair of the Association of American Law Schools Section on Evidence.
Name: Michael S. Pardo

Value: K-Sue Park’s scholarship examines the development of American property law and the creation of the American real estate market through the histories of colonization and enslavement.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: She teaches first-year Property and a seminar entitled Land, Dispossession, and Displacement.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: Previously, she was the Critical Race Studies Fellow at UCLA School of Law and an Equal Justice Works Fellow and staff attorney in El Paso, where she investigated predatory mortgage lending schemes as part of Texas RioGrande Legal Aid’s foreclosure defense team.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: Park earned her B.A. summa cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa honors from Cornell University, where she was a College Scholar, her M.Phil with Distinction in Social and Political Sciences from the University of Cambridge, her J.D. cum laude from Harvard Law School, where she was a Presidential Scholar, and her Ph.D. in Rhetoric from UC Berkeley, where she was a Javits Fellow.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: She was also a Fulbright Scholar in South Korea in 2003.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: In 2015, her article, “Money, Mortgages, and the Conquest of America” won the American Bar Foundation’s graduate student paper competition and the Association for Law, Culture and the Humanities’ Austin Sarat Award, and was selected for the Law and Humanities Junior Scholar Workshop.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: Her publications have appeared or are forthcoming in the Harvard Law Review, the Yale Law Journal, The University of Chicago Law Review, The History of the Present, Law & Social Inquiry, and the New York Times.
Name: K-Sue Park

Value: Professor Eloise Pasachoff focuses her teaching and writing in the areas of administrative law and education law.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Her scholarship has earned national awards in both fields.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: In 2017, the American Bar Association’s Administrative Law Section gave The President’s Budget as a Source of Agency Policy Control, 125 Yale L. J. 2182 (2016), one of its annual scholarship awards.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: In 2012, the Education Law Association awarded Special Education, Poverty, and the Limits of Private Enforcement, 86 Notre Dame L. Rev. 1413 (2011), its Steven S. Goldberg Award for Distinguished Scholarship.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Professor Pasachoff is a dedicated teacher.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: In 2017, Georgetown Law honored Professor Pasachoff with the Frank Flegal Teaching Award.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Between 2016 and 2019, she served as chair of the clerkships committee, devoting a lot of her time to helping students secure state and federal clerkships.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Starting in 2019, she became Associate Dean for Careers.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Professor Pasachoff is a public member of the Administrative Conference of the United States, an independent federal agency that works on improvements to public administration, management, and administrative procedure.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: She has also been active in the Association of American Law Schools, serving as chair of the Education Law Section and on the scholarship committee, as well as presenting at the AALS Workshop for New Law School Teachers.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: She is a member of the American Law Institute and serves on the Academic Advisory Board of the Supreme Court Fellows program.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Professor Pasachoff received an A.B. summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard, an M.A. from Yale, an M.P.A. from Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, and a J.D. magna cum laude from Harvard Law School, where she was an executive editor of the Harvard Civil Rights-Civil Liberties Law Review.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: After law school, she served as a law clerk to Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, Judge Robert A. Katzmann of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, and Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court of the United States.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: She also worked as a litigation associate at WilmerHale LLP in New York City.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Immediately before joining the faculty at Georgetown, she taught first-year legal research and writing as a Climenko Fellow and Lecturer on Law at Harvard Law School.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: Earlier in her career, she taught middle and high school English in public and private schools in New York City.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: She is a past chair of the Committee on Education and the Law of the New York City Bar Association and served on the board of the Pine Cobble School in Williamstown, Massachusetts for seven years.
Name: Eloise Pasachoff

Value: After graduating from law school, where he served on the Harvard Law Review and won the Sears Prize, Professor Peller clerked for the Honorable Morris Lasker of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.
Name: Gary Peller

Value: He was a member of the University of Virginia Law faculty from 1982-1988 prior to joining the Georgetown faculty.
Name: Gary Peller

Value: He has taught Constitutional Law, Contracts, Torts, Civil Rights, Bargain, Exchange & Liability, Criminal Procedure, Radical Legal Thought, and Jurisprudence at Georgetown.
Name: Gary Peller

Value: His writings are primarily in the field of legal theory and legal history.
Name: Gary Peller

Value: His most recent book is Critical Race Consciousness: Reconsidering American Ideologies of Racial Justice (Paradigm 2012).
Name: Gary Peller

Value: Professor Jonah E. Perlin teaches legal practice and advanced legal writing.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: Before coming to the Law Center he worked for several years as a litigator at Williams & Connolly LLP in Washington, D.C. where he specialized in complex civil litigation in the United States and abroad.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: While at Williams & Connolly he also taught advanced legal writing at the Law Center as an Adjunct Professor.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: Professor Perlin clerked for Chief Judge Robert A. Katzmann of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: Professor Perlin received his J.D., magna cum laude, from the Law Center in 2012, where he was an Articles Editor for the Georgetown Law Journal and a law fellow in the Legal Research and Writing Program.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: He received his A.B., magna cum laude, from Princeton University and his A.M. in Religious Studies from the University of Chicago Divinity School.
Name: Jonah E. Perlin

Value: Alicia Plerhoples is a Professor of Law and the Director of the Social Enterprise & Nonprofit Law Clinic.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Professor Plerhoples is a leading scholar in social enterprise law, nonprofit governance, and clinical legal education.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Professor Plerhoples joined the faculty at Georgetown University Law Center in 2012, where she is director of the Social Enterprise & Nonprofit Law Clinic.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Professor Plerhoples is active in the social enterprise legal sector, advising clients and organizations on governance arrangements and organizational structures that facilitate the work of social entrepreneurs.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: In 2017, Professor Plerhoples received the American Bar Association’s Outstanding Nonprofit Lawyer of the Year (Academic) Award.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: She serves on the Legal Advisory Group of Echoing Green, a global nonprofit which identifies, incubates, and funds social entrepreneurs.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Examples of Professor Plerhoples’ recent research articles include integrating social enterprise into poor communities, pursuit of charity through public benefit corporations, and how to apply traditional corporate law principles to new social enterprise legislation.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Her publications have appeared in the Lewis & Clark Law Review, Washington University Journal of Law and Policy, and the International Journal of Clinical Legal Education, among others.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Professor Plerhoples previously was the Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe Clinical Teaching Fellow at Stanford Law School and a Visiting Assistant Professor at University of California Hastings College of the Law.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Prior to entering academia, she practiced with the law firms of DLA Piper in New York City and Cooley in Silicon Valley.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Professor Plerhoples graduated from Yale Law School in 2005 and holds a master’s degree in Public Administration from Princeton University’s Woodrow Wilson School of International and Public Policy.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: She completed her A.B., cum laude, from Harvard College in 2001.
Name: Alicia Plerhoples

Value: Dave Rapallo joined the faculty as Clinic Director after spending 23 years in high-level positions in Congress and the White House.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: For the past decade, Dave served as Staff Director of the House Committee on Oversight and Reform under then-Chairman Elijah E. Cummings and Chairwoman Carolyn B. Maloney.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: He supervised a team of more than 70 attorneys, investigators, legislative experts, and communications staff, as well as the Committee’s five subcommittees, and oversaw a broad range of legislative efforts.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: During President Barack Obama’s first term, Dave served as Senior Director and Counsel for Legislative Oversight at the National Security Council, working directly with the offices of the Chief of Staff, White House Counsel, and Legislative Affairs.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: Dave previously served as General Counsel on the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and as Chief Investigative Counsel on the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform under then-Chairman Henry A. Waxman.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: Dave has served on or advised several special committees, including those investigating the events of Hurricane Katrina, the attacks in Benghazi, and the coronavirus pandemic, and he served on the House of Representatives’ team during the impeachment of President Donald Trump.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: Dave also served as one of the Clinic’s first Teaching Fellows in the 1990s under the Clinic’s founder, Chai Feldblum.
Name: Dave Rapallo

Value: Mitt Regan is McDevitt Professor of Jurisprudence, Director  of the Center on the Legal Profession, and Co-Director on the Center on  National Security and the Law at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: His work  focuses on international law, national security, international human rights,  and legal and military ethics.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: Professor Regan is also Senior Fellow at the Stockdale  Center for Ethical Leadership at the U.S. Naval Academy, and Adjunct Faculty  Member at the Center for Military and Security Law at the Australian National  University College of Law.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: He is a participant in two major interdisciplinary research  projects: Global Terrorism and Collective  Responsibility, funded by the European Research Council, and Split-Second Morality: Protecting Civilians  in Asymmetric Conflicts, funded by the Georgetown University program on  complex moral problems.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: Professor Regan’s work on ethics includes Eat What You Kill: The Fall of a Wall Street  Lawyer; Confidence Games: Lawyers,  Accountants, and the Tax Shelter  Industry (with Tanina Rostain; and Professional  Responsibility: Representing Business Organizations (with John K. Villa)
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: He  also is the author of two books that analyze family law through the lens of the  debate between liberal and communication political philosophy, Alone Together: Law and the Meanings of  Marriage and Family Law and the  Pursuit of Intimacy.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: He is the co-editor with Anita Allen of Debating Democracy’s Discontent: Essays on  American Politics, Law and Public Philosophy.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: Before joining Georgetown, Professor Regan was an associate  at the law firm of Davis Polk and Wardwell, and served as law clerk to Justice  William J. Brennan, Jr. on the U.S. Supreme Court and then-Judge Ruth Bader  Ginsburg on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.
Name: Mitt Regan, Jr.

Value: Professor Rogers previously was an Associate Professor of Law at Temple University Beasley School of Law.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: He teaches torts, employment law, employment discrimination, and various labor law courses.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: Professor Rogers’ current research explores the relationship among labor and employment law, technological development, and economic and social equality.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: He is writing a book on those questions, entitled Rethinking the Future of Work: Law, Technology, and Economic Citizenship (under contract with MIT University Press).
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: In addition to his law review publications, he has recently written for the Boston Review, the Washington Post Outlook, Onlabor.org, and ACSblog, the blog of the American Constitution Society.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: Professor Rogers’ scholarship has been cited in landmark decisions by the California Supreme Court and the European Court of Justice.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: Professor Rogers received his J.D., cum laude, from Harvard Law School and his B.A., with high distinction from the University of Virginia.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: Prior to law school, he worked as a community organizer promoting living wage policies and affordable housing, and spent several years organizing workers as part of SEIU’s “Justice for Janitors” campaign.
Name: Brishen Rogers

Value: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz teaches constitutional law and federal jurisdiction, and he writes articles for the Harvard Law Review and the Stanford Law Review.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He is currently developing a new theory of constitutional interpretation and judicial review.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: The first installment, entitled The Subjects of the Constitution, was published in the Stanford Law Review in May of 2010, and it is among the most downloaded articles about constitutional interpretation, judicial review, and/or federal courts in the history of SSRN.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: The second installment, The Objects of the Constitution, was published in May of 2011, also in the Stanford Law Review.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: And the comprehensive version is forthcoming as a book by Oxford University Press.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: Rosenkranz has served and advised the federal government in a variety of capacities.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He clerked for Judge Frank H. Easterbrook on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit (1999-2000) and for Justice Anthony M. Kennedy at the U.S. Supreme Court (October Term 2001).
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He served as an Attorney-Advisor at the Office of Legal Counsel in the U.S. Department of Justice (November 2002 – July 2004).
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He often testifies before Congress as a constitutional expert—most recently before the House Financial Services Oversight Subcommittee, regarding the Obama Administration’s use of bank settlement agreements to circumvent the Appropriations Clause.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He has also filed briefs and presented oral argument before the U.S. Supreme Court.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: His most recent Supreme Court brief, in Los Angeles v. Patel, was cited by Justice Alito in dissent.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: Rosenkranz is a member of the New York Bar and the U.S. Supreme Court Bar.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He is a Senior Fellow at the Cato Institute.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He serves on the Board of Directors of the William F. Buckley Program at Yale.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He is a founding member of Heterodox Academy and a member of its Executive Committee.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: He also serves on the Board of Directors of the Federalist Society; and as the faculty advisor to the Georgetown chapter.
Name: Nicholas Quinn Rosenkranz

Value: Professor Ross teaches International and Comparative Law on Women’s Human Rights and is the Director of the International Women’s Human Rights Clinic, which she founded in 1998.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In the Clinic, students work to advance women’s human rights through litigation, legislation, and human rights reporting in partnership with women’s NGOs in many developing countries, especially in Africa.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She was also Director of the Sex Discrimination Clinic, where students litigated on behalf of victims of sex-based employment discrimination and domestic violence (1983-1998).
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Finally, she started and served as Director of the Women’s Law and Public Policy Fellowship Program (1983-1998) and its Leadership and Advocacy for Women in Africa Program (1993-1998).
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Her most recent book, a first in its field, is Women’s Human Rights:
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: The International and Comparative Law Casebook (2008), with an on-line documentary supplement, RossRights.com.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She co-authored one of the first two casebooks on women’s rights issues, Sex Discrimination and the Law: Causes and Remedies(1975), as well as Sex Discrimination and the Law: History, Practice, and Theory(1996), focusing on remedies for sex-based employment discrimination.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In other books and articles, she has written about parental leave, sexual harassment, domestic violence, polygyny as a violation of women’s human rights, and the role of fact-finding in advancing women’s human rights.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She served as Reporter to the Uniform Laws Commission’s Drafting Committee for a Uniform Act on Prevention of and Remedies for Human Trafficking, from 2011 to 2013, when the Act was adopted.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She was also Co-Chair of the Special Committee on Gender for the D.C. Circuit Task Force on Gender, Race, and Ethnic Bias, which met from 1992-1995 and published its report in 1996.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She served as Co-Chair of the Campaign to End Discrimination against Pregnant Workers from 1976 to 1978;in that capacity, she testified before Congress for enactment of the Pregnancy Discrimination
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Act of 1978, which was needed to reverse the Supreme Court’s holding in General Electric Co. v. Gilbert, 429 U.S. 125 (1976), that discrimination against pregnant workers was not prohibited sex discrimination within the meaning of Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: She was also a leading advocate for enactment of the Family and Medical Leave
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Act of 1993, testifying before Congress and helping to ensure that it provided leave to both women and men and not just women, as originally envisioned.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Before joining the faculty in 1983, she was Special Counsel for Sex Discrimination Litigation at the U.S. Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division, and before that the Clinical Director of the ACLU’s Women’s Rights Project.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Other experience included work at the General Counsel’s office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and a year of private practice with Bellamy, Blank, Goodman, Kelly, Ross and Stanley.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: During those years, she also taught early women and the law courses as an adjunct at GW, NYU, Rutgers, and Columbia Law Schools;at GW, she was also a visiting professor.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: At the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division, her litigation resulted in Kentucky women prisoners gaining the right to equal vocational training programs with men and in thousands of Rhode Island mothers receiving more than $2,000,000 to compensate them for the state having denied them the PDA-required paid sick leave other workers received under a Rhode Island statute.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Her ACLU Women’s Rights Project litigation helped establish women’s right to equal pension benefits with men, both at the federal trial level (Peters v. Wayne State University in 1979) and Supreme Court (Los Angeles Department of Water &Power v. Manhart in 1978).
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: While a Hays Civil Liberties Fellow at N.Y.U. Law School, she wrote the ACLU amicus brief for Phillips v. Martin Marietta Corp., the Supreme Court decision that employers could not refuse to hire mothers –when they hired fathers –of pre-school age children, the Court’s first Title VII sex discrimination case.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Before law school, she was a Peace Corps volunteer in Ivory Coast (1965-1967), and her work with the International Women’s Human Rights Clinic has enabled her to work now with many prominent African women’s rights lawyers to advance women’s rights in their countries.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Using human rights projects prepared by Clinic students under her leadership, Clinic partners have succeeded in winning new laws prohibiting domestic violence and sex-based employment discrimination in both Ghana and Uganda.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In addition, in Ghana, they won new laws prohibiting trafficking and in Uganda, female genital mutilation.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Victorious lawsuits in the Uganda Constitutional Court struck down sex-discriminatory laws concerning divorce (husbands could divorce for adultery, but wives could not), criminal adultery (married women could be prosecuted for adultery with an unmarried man, but married men were immune from such prosecution for adultery with an unmarried woman), and inheritance (e.g., intestacy provisions denied the surviving widow, but not the widower, ownership of the matrimonial home and lands;ownership was granted instead to the eldest son).
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In Tanzania, the Clinic and the Women’s Legal Aid Centre partnered to win a victory before the U.N. Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women in 2015;it ruled that Tanzania’s customary law denying widows any inheritance, prohibiting women from inheriting clan land or administering estates, and granting sons much more personal property than daughters violated the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In 2019, the Clinic learned that its partners in Kenya and Eswatini (formerly, Swaziland) had won important court victories with the help of the Clinic’s work.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: In Kenya, a High Court struck down laws giving unwed fathers the “optional paternity” right to avoid all financial responsibility for their children; the Court ruled that under Kenya’s Constitution, “fathers and mothers have equal responsibility to a child they bear, and this responsibility is not left to the volition of the man or woman.”
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: And in Eswatini, another High Court held that the common law rule that married women are subject to their husband’s marital power, and the statutory rule that “African” wives should be subject to their husband’s Swazi marital power unless they opted out before marriage, discriminated against married women and offended their constitutional rights to dignity and equality.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Both rules gave husbands the right to make unilateral decisions over property and other matters; they treated adult women as minor children.
Name: Susan Deller Ross

Value: Tanina Rostain’s current scholarly and teaching interests focus on access to the civil justice system and the function of legal technologies developed to bridge the justice gap.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Her research explores the opportunities and limits of digital tools to provide information about and access to the legal system.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Rostain’s work also considers how data science can be used to produce knowledge about legal problems and the efficacy of interventions to address them.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Recently, Professor Rostain launched the Justice Lab at Georgetown, a research center dedicated to studying the various modalities emerging to address unmet legal needs.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: The Lab’s initiatives include studies of “low bono” law firms and legal “navigators,” and a national multi-county investigation of different forms of assistance that are provided to self-represented litigants.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Rostain’s research interest in technology and access to the civil legal system dates back to 2012, when she created a course in which student teams work with non-profit legal service providers to build apps that increase access to the legal system.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Professor Rostain’s earlier academic work explored the ethical challenges that arise in corporate and tax practice and focused on the influences of organizational context on professional misconduct.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: In 2014, she published Confidence Games: Lawyers, Accountants, and the Tax Shelter Industry (MIT Press).
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Co-authored with Professor Mitt Regan, Confidence Games examines the role of major accounting firms and corporate firms in the rise of the tax shelter industry at the turn of the 21st Century.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Rostain has also authored articles on tax and corporate law practice.
Name: Tanina Rostain

Value: Professor Rothstein is well known for his work in evidence; torts; civil and criminal lawsuits; governmental, legal, and judicial ethics; and the judicial process from the Supreme Court on down, including constitutional aspects.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: His background is that of a practicing trial lawyer handling tort, criminal, and commercial litigation.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He is author of the books Evidence: Cases, Materials and Problems; Evidence in a Nutshell; Federal Rules of Evidence; Federal Testimonial Privileges and several other books and approximately 100 articles.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: His numerous professional activities include positions as chair of the American Bar Association Rules of Evidence and Criminal Procedure Committee, Board member and Education Chairman of the Federal Bar Association, chair of the Association of American Law Schools Evidence Section, and consultant to the U.S Congress, the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws, and the National Academy of Sciences.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: In addition, he has been a regular contributing editor to the Legal Times, the New York Law Journal, and the Criminal Law Bulletin and on the Publication Advisory Boards of Matthew Bender Co., Lexis-Nexis, and several other publishers.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Professor Rothstein was a Fulbright Scholar at Oxford University in England prior to entering the profession.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Professor Rothstein was on the American team helping draft the constitutions of approximately a dozen countries emerging from the former Soviet Union, including Russia.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He also was a pioneer in government compensation for victims of crime, helping draft some of the earliest American legislation and playing an instrumental role in the formation of the American and International Crime Victims Compensation Associations, in which he was an officer.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He has been a principal consultant to both houses of Congress on revision of the massive U.S. Criminal Code and on the Federal Rules of Evidence; and has advised states, such as Texas, and D.C., on the revision of their criminal codes, and states and countries considering codification of rules of evidence, including New York and Canada.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He has trained federal and state judges at the Federal Judicial Center and the National Judicial College, the principal agencies for the education of federal and state judges, respectively.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Rothstein also was consultant to the IRS and Treasury Department in the drafting of successful mutual assistance treaties with Switzerland and other countries, providing (for the first time in several instances) much needed cross-border procedures for obtaining testimony and other evidence in criminal cases.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He was also consultant on electronic evidence to the National Commission on Restructuring the Internal Revenue Service, as well as to the Georgetown University Project on Scientific Validity and the Courts.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: His books and long-running series of articles and conference programs for judges and attorneys on the Federal Rules of Evidence, together with his chairmanship of the Association of American Law Schools Evidence Section and of an American Bar Association Committee studying the Rules, are credited with advancing in a major way professionalism and competence in the use and teaching of the Rules.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He has designed and run trial-lawyer training programs for the Justice Department and other government agencies and leading Washington law firms; and has run a federal public defender service.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: He has represented prominent public figures, and has been invited to write Friend of the Court briefs in several important Supreme Court cases, including two of the leading evidence cases and a petition for certiorari in a case involving President Bill and Hillary Clinton and Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: The Supreme Court has cited his work.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Professor Rothstein is also frequently sought out as a public commentator on many of the important legal developments of our times.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Rothstein has been notified by SSRN he is currently among their “top 10% of authors by all-time downloads.”
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: In addition several of his new articles individually are on SSRN’s top ten list, including (1) “A Game of Katso and Mouse: Current Theories for Getting Forensic Analysis Evidence Past the Confrontation Clause” (Dec.10, 2018, concerning latest Scotus Confrontation Clause developments) (with RJ Coleman), forthcoming Am. Crim. L. Rev. Vol. 57, available now at  http://ssrn.com/abstract=3299670Links to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: or  https://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/facpub/2114Links to an external site. ; and (2) “Demystifying Burdens of Proof and the Effect of Rebuttable Evidentiary Presumptions in Civil and Criminal Trials” (80 pp.) available at  https://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/facpub/2001Links to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: or  https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3050687Links to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: 2019 also saw BRAND NEW EDITIONS of several Rothstein BOOKS: (1) EVIDENCE: CASES, MATERIALS & PROBLEMS (5th ed. 2019, Carolina Academic Press; lots new stuff plus copious teachers’ manual) (with David Crump & Tamara Lawson); (2) FEDERAL RULES OF EVIDENCE (2019, Thomson-Reuters-West; hard copy & also on Westlaw); and (3) FEDERAL TESTIMONIAL PRIVILEGES (2019, Thomson-Reuters-West; hard copy & also on Westlaw) (with Susan Crump).
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: You may also be interested in his full doctrine-of-chances piece in the Oxford Univ. peer-reviewed Journal of Law, Probability & Risk at  https://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/facpub/1481Links to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: or  http://ssrn.com/abstract=2603872Links to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: and his debate with Prof. Imwinkelried on FRE 608 at  https://dspace2.creighton.edu/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10504/84525/49CreightonLRev121.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=yLinks to an external site.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: that attracted legendary Judge Jack Weinstein’s kudos.
Name: Paul F. Rothstein

Value: Professor Hillary A. Sale is an award-winning teacher, a Professor of Law at Georgetown Law, and an Affiliated Faculty Member at the McDonough School of Business at Georgetown University.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: She teaches courses on Leadership, Women and Leadership, and Corporate Law and Governance.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: In the spring of 2017, she was the Sullivan & Cromwell Visiting Professor of Law at Harvard Law School, where she taught Women’s Leadership and Corporate Boards and Governance.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: She is an expert on and frequent speaker to industry groups and academic audiences about leadership and corporate governance and was selected by the St. Louis Business Journal as a “2014 Most Influential Business Women.”
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: In addition to running leadership and other programs in industry, Professor Sale has taught in multiple executive education programs, including the Harvard Law School Law Firm Leaders Program and various programs through the Washington University Olin School of Business.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Professor Sale is a member of the FINRA Board of Governors, where she serves on the Nominating and Governance, Compensation, and Regulatory Operations Committees.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: She is also a member of the Advisory Board of Foundation Press, and the Advisory Board of DirectWomen, a nonprofit with the mission of increasing the presence of women on public company boards.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: She is Chair of the DirectWomen Board Institute and also works in industry training executives on leadership, governance, and risk management.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Professor
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Sale is a leading scholar in the areas of corporate governance and the role of corporate and securities law in shaping board decision-making and strategies and has authored many award-winning articles.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Professor Sale is co-author (with John C. Coffee, Jr. and Charles K. Whitehead) of the book Securities Regulation and is a member of the Committee on Corporate Laws of the ABA, where she co-chaired the task force for the Sixth Edition of the Corporate Director’s Guidebook.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Professor Sale is also a Fellow of the American College of Governance Counsel.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Before entering academia, Sale was a law clerk to The Honorable Richard S. Arnold, Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, practiced with the law firm of WilmerHale LLP, and was Chief of Staff and Director of Operations for Evelyn F. Murphy, the Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard Law School in 1993 and holds a master’s degree in Economics from Boston University, where she also completed her B.A., summa cum laude in 1983.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: From 1997-2009, she was a member of the University of Iowa College of Law, where she was the F. Arnold Daum Chair in Corporate Finance and Law, and from 2009-2018, she was the Walter D. Coles Professor of Law and a Professor of Management at Washington University in St. Louis.
Name: Hillary Sale

Value: Professor Salop teaches courses in Antitrust Law, Economic Reasoning and the Law, and had conducted a Faculty Workshop in Law and Economics.
Name: Steven C. Salop

Value: His recent writings include several articles that focus on exclusionary conduct, including articles on the antitrust standard for exclusionary conduct, exclusionary conduct by buyers, and the antitrust standard for refusals to deal and price squeezes.
Name: Steven C. Salop

Value: Professor Salop has other articles on the consumer welfare standard, raising rivals’ cost conduct, the first principles approach to antitrust, and vertical mergers.
Name: Steven C. Salop

Value: His research focuses on antitrust law and economics and economic analysis of industrial competition and imperfect information.
Name: Steven C. Salop

Value: Before joining the Law Center faculty in 1981, he served as Associate Director for Special Projects with the Bureau of Economics of the FTC, as an adjunct professor of economics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he received his B.A. in 1968, and as an economist with the Civil Aeronautics Board and Federal Reserve Board.
Name: Steven C. Salop

Value: Alvaro Santos is Professor of Law and Faculty Director of the Center for the Advancement of the Rule of Law in the Americas (CAROLA) at Georgetown Law.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He teaches and writes in the areas of international trade, economic development, transnational labor law and drug policy.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: In 2018, he served as Deputy Chief Negotiator of the USMCA Agreement for the newly elected government of Mexico.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: Professor Santos is co-editor of the books World Trade and Investment Law Reimagined: A Progressive Agenda for an Inclusive Globalization (2019), Law and the New Developmental State: The Brazilian Experience in Latin America (2013) and The New Law and Economic Development: A Critical Appraisal (2006).
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He is also the author of numerous journal articles and book chapters.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He serves on the editorial boards of the American Journal of Comparative Law, the Journal of International Economic Law, the Law and Development Review, and the Latin American Journal of International Trade Law.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He served as Co-Director of the Center for Transnational Legal Studies (CTLS) in London in 2014-15.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He regularly teaches at Georgetown’s Global Trade Academy and Harvard’s Institute for Global Law and Policy (IGLP) and has also taught at the University of Texas, Tufts University, Melbourne Law School, Centro de Investigación y Docencia Económicas (CIDE), and the University of Turin.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: He received an LL.B. with high honors from Universidad Nacional Autonóma de México (UNAM) and an LLM and SJD from Harvard Law School.
Name: Alvaro Santos

Value: Effective July 1, 2021, Professor Satterthwaite arrives at the Law Center from University of Toronto Faculty of Law.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Her research focuses on the law of taxation and examines areas in which taxpayer choices and compliance obligations may have unanticipated equity implications.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: She uses experimental, qualitative, and quantitative empirical methods to study how the design of elective provisions in tax statutes and tax agency enforcement policies plays out “on the ground,” with a particular focus on entry-level entrepreneurs and self-employed individuals.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Her recent work has explored the impact of value-added tax registration thresholds on micro-entrepreneurs, the relationship of entrepreneurs’ legal and tax status choices to their firms’ chances for survival, and how audit policies can be presented to taxpayers to support their post-audit compliance choices.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Her published and current research has received support from Canada’s federal Social Science and Humanities Research Council, Foundation for Legal Research, the University of Toronto’s Connaught Fund, and other grantors.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Prior to serving as a full-time faculty member at the University of Toronto Faculty of Law, Professor Satterthwaite earned her M.A. (economics) and her LL.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: M. from the University of Toronto.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Before that, she was the Assistant Director of the Institute for Justice Clinic on Entrepreneurship at the University of Chicago Law School, where she supervised second- and third-year law students in their representation of early-stage businesses launched by lower-income entrepreneurs.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: She also practiced for three years as an associate at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP in New York and Chicago.
Name: Emily Satterthwaite

Value: Andrew I. Schoenholtz is a Professor from Practice at Georgetown Law, where he co-directs the Center for Applied Legal Studies, the asylum clinic in which students represent refugees fleeing persecution who seek asylum in the United States.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: He also directs the Human Rights Institute and the Certificate in Refugees and Humanitarian Emergencies.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: He has taught courses on Refugee Law and Policy, Refugees and Humanitarian Emergencies, and Immigration Law and Policy, as well as a practicum on the rights of detained immigrants.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: Prior to teaching at Georgetown, Professor Schoenholtz served as Deputy Director of the US Commission on Immigration Reform.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: He also practiced immigration, asylum, and international law with the Washington, DC law firm of Covington & Burling.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: He has conducted fact-finding missions in Haiti, Cuba, Ecuador, Germany, Croatia, Bosnia, Malawi, and Zambia to study root causes of forced migration, refugee protection, long-term solutions to mass migration emergencies, and humanitarian relief operations.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: Professor Schoenholtz researches and writes regularly on refugee law and policy.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: His publications include: The End of Asylum (co-author);
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: The Promise and Challenge of Humanitarian Protection in the United States: Making Temporary Protected Status Work as a Safe Haven; The New Refugees and the Old Treaty:   Persecutors and Persecuted in the Twenty-First Century; Lives in the Balance: Asylum Adjudication by the Department of Homeland Security (co-author); Rejecting Refugees: Homeland Security’s Administration of the One-Year Bar to Asylum (co-author); Refugee Roulette:  Disparities in Asylum Adjudication (co-author); Refugee Protection in the United States Post-September 11th; The Uprooted:  Improving Humanitarian Responses to Forced Migration (chapter on “Improving Legal Frameworks”); and Aiding and Abetting Persecutors: The Seizure and Return of Haitian Refugees in Violation of the UN Refugee Convention and Protocol.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: Dr. Schoenholtz holds a JD from Harvard Law School and a PhD from Brown University.
Name: Andrew I. Schoenholtz

Value: Professor Schrag teaches Professional Responsibility and co-directs the Center for Applied Legal Studies, in which students represent refugees from persecution who are seeking asylum in the United States.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: He has also taught civil procedure, administrative law, legislation, and consumer protection law.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: He served for 21 years as the Director of the Public Interest Law Scholars Program, through which selected law students who plan careers as public interest lawyers receive scholarship grants and special academic enrichment and guidance in that field.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Before joining the Law Center faculty in 1981, he was assistant counsel to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Consumer Advocate of the City of New York, a professor at Columbia University Law School, and Deputy General Counsel of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, from which he received a Meritorious Honor Award in 1981.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Professor Schrag has also had a distinguished and varied career in civic service, which has included positions as a delegate to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention in 1982, an editor and consultant on consumer protection during the Carter-Mondale transition, a consultant to the New York State Consumer Protection Board, a consultant to the Governor’s Advisory Council of Puerto Rico, and an Academic Specialist for the United States Information Agency in the Czech Republic and Hungary.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: In addition, he drafted New York City’s Consumer Protection Act of 1969.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: He is also a prolific author, having written dozens of articles on consumer law, nuclear arms control, political asylum, and various other topics for both law journals and popular publications.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: He is the author of seventeen books, including The End of Asylum (with Andrew I. Schoenholtz and Jaya Ramji-Nogales 2021), Baby Jails: The Fight to End the Incarceration of Refugee Children in America (2020);
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Ethical Problems in the Practice of Law (5th edition 2020, with Lisa G. Lerman and Robert Rubinson);
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Lives in the Balance: Asylum Adjudication by the Department of Homeland Security (with Jaya Ramji-Nogales and Andrew I. Schoenholtz, 2014);
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Refugee Roulette: Disparities in Asylum Adjudication and Proposals for Reform (with Jaya Ramji-Nogales and Andrew I. Schoenholtz, 2009);
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: Asylum Denied: A Refugee’s Struggle for Safety in America (with David Ngaruri Kenney, 2008); A Well-founded Fear: The Congressional Battle to Save Political Asylum in America; andReflections on Clinical Legal Education (with Michael Meltsner, 1998).
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: He has been honored with Georgetown University’s Presidential Award for Distinguished Teacher/Scholars; Equal Justice Works’s Outstanding Law Faculty Member Award for leadership in nurturing a spirit of public service in legal education and beyond; Lexis/Nexis’s Daniel Levy Memorial Award for outstanding achievement in immigration Law; and the Association of American Law Schools William Pincus Award for service to clinical legal education and its Deborah L. Rhode Award for contributions to increasing pro bono and public service opportunities in law schools through scholarship, service, and leadership.
Name: Philip G. Schrag

Value: After graduating from Harvard Law School in 1971, Professor Seidman served as a law clerk for J. Skelly Wright of the D.C. Circuit and U.S. Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: He then was a staff attorney with the D.C. Public Defender Service until joining the Law Center faculty in 1976.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: He has been a visiting professor at Harvard Law School, The University of Chicago Law School, New York University Law School, and the University of Virginia Law School.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: He teaches a variety of courses in the fields of constitutional and criminal law.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: He is co-author of a constitutional law casebook and the author of many articles concerning criminal justice and constitutional law.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: His most recent books are On Constitutional Disobedience (Oxford, 2012);
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: Silence and Freedom (Stanford 2007);
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: Equal Protection of the Laws (Foundation 2002);and Our Unsettled Constitution: A New Defense of Constitutionalism and Judicial Review (Yale 2001).
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: In 2011, Seidman was elected to membership in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Name: Louis Michael Seidman

Value: Howard Shelanski earned his B.A. from Haverford College and received his J.D. and Ph.D. in economics from the University of California at Berkeley.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: After graduating from law school he clerked for Judge Stephen F. Williams of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, Judge Louis H. Pollak of the U.S. District Court in Philadelphia, and Justice Antonin Scalia of the United States Supreme Court.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: After practicing law in Washington, D.C., Professor Shelanski joined the Berkeley faculty in 1997, where he remained until coming to Georgetown in 2011.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: Professor Shelanski has held several positions in the federal government.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: From 2013 to 2017, he served as Administrator of the White House Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA).
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: Before President Obama nominated him to OIRA, Professor Shelanski was Director of the Bureau of Economics at the Federal Trade Commission from 2012 to 2013, where he had previously been Deputy Director from 2009 to 2011.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: Earlier in his career, he was Chief Economist of the Federal Communications Commission (1999-2000) and a Senior Economist for the President’s Council of Economic Advisers at the White House (1998-1999).
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: In addition to being a member of the Georgetown Law faculty, Professor Shelanski practices antitrust law and is a member of the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: Professor Shelanski’s teaching and research focus on antitrust and regulation.
Name: Howard Shelanski

Value: In addition to numerous articles, he has co-authored leading casebooks, treatises and edited volumes in both antitrust and telecommunications law.

Value: Immediately prior to joining the full-time Law Center faculty in 2007, Professor Sirota was an attorney for the Professional Responsibility Advisory Office of the U.S. Department of Justice, where she advised and trained lawyers on professional responsibility issues in criminal and civil matters.

Value: She also taught Professional Responsibility as an adjunct faculty member.

Value: Previously, Professor Sirota was Counsel for Ethics and Administration for the Environment and Natural Resources Division of the Department of Justice.
Name: Rima Sirota

Value: Before joining the government, she was a partner at Baach Robinson & Lewis, where she practiced civil litigation.
Name: Rima Sirota

Value: Professor Sirota also served for six years as an appointed hearing committee member for the District of Columbia Board on Professional Responsibility.
Name: Rima Sirota

Value: Professor Sirota currently serves as Ethics Counsel to the D.C. Volunteer Lawyers Project.

Value: She is also a member of the DCVLP Advisory Council.
Name: Rima Sirota

Value: B.A., summa cum laude, Yale; J.D., magna cum laude, Harvard.

Value: Professor Smiley is a Professor in the Graduate Tax Program of the Law Center and Senior Counsel of the law firm of Caplin &Drysdale, Chartered.
Name: Stafford Smiley

Value: He specializes in the taxation of corporate and noncorporate business entities, intergenerational wealth planning and international transactions.
Name: Stafford Smiley

Value: He is also a Professor at the University of Lodz in Poland and serves or has served as a Visiting Professor in graduate tax programs in Austria, Australia, Brazil, China and the Russian Federation.

Value: Prior to entering law practice, he served as a law clerk to Judge Arnold Raum of the United States Tax Court.

Value: Abbe Smith is Director of the Criminal Defense and Prisoner Advocacy Clinic, Co-Director of the E. Barrett Prettyman Fellowship Program, and Professor of Law at Georgetown University.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: She joined the Georgetown faculty in 1996.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Prior to Georgetown, Professor Smith was Deputy Director of the Criminal Justice Institute at Harvard Law School, and a Clinical Instructor and Lecturer on Law at Harvard.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Professor Smith has also taught at the City University New York School of Law, Temple University School of Law, American University Washington College of Law, and the University of Melbourne Law School (Australia), where she was a Senior Fulbright Scholar in 2005-06.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Professor Smith teaches and writes on criminal defense, legal ethics, juvenile justice, and clinical legal education.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: In addition to numerous law journal articles, she is the author of Case of a Lifetime: A Criminal Defense Lawyer’s Story (Palgrave MacMillan, 2008), co-author with Monroe Freedman of Understanding Lawyers’
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Ethics (4th ed., Lexis-Nexis, 2010), co-editor with Monroe Freedman of How Can You Represent Those People: Criminal Defense Stories (forthcoming, 2013), co-author with Charles Ogletree, et al. of Beyond the Rodney King Story: An Investigation of Police Conduct In Minority Communities  (Northeastern University Press, 1994), and a contributing author of We Dissent (Michael Avery, ed., NYU Press, 2008) and Law Stories (Gary Bellow & Martha Minow, eds., University of Michigan Press, 1996).
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Professor Smith began her legal career at the Defender Association of Philadelphia, where she was an Assistant Defender, a member of the Special Defense Unit, and a Senior Trial Attorney from 1982 to 1990.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: She continues to be actively engaged in indigent defense—as both a clinical supervisor and member of the Criminal Justice Act panel for the DC Superior Court—and frequently presents at public defender and legal aid training programs in the United States and abroad.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Professor Smith is on the Board of Directors of The Bronx Defenders and the National Juvenile Defender Center, and a longtime member of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the American Civil Liberties Union, and the National Lawyers Guild Court.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: In 2010, she was elected to the American Board of Criminal Lawyers, an exclusive national society for outstanding criminal trial lawyers.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Professor Smith is also a published cartoonist.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: A collection of her cartoons, Carried Away:
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: The Chronicles of a Feminist Cartoonist, was published by Sanguinaria Publishing, Inc. in1984.
Name: Abbe Smith

Value: Paul M. Smith is also the Vice President for Litigation and Strategy at the Campaign Legal Center.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Until 2017 he was in private practice at the firm of Jenner & Block LLP.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: He had an active appellate practice for several decades, including oral arguments in 21 Supreme Court cases in a wide range of cases but emphasizing civil rights and civil liberties issues.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Among his important victories have been Lawrence v. Texas, the landmark gay rights case, and Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Ass’n, establishing the First Amendment rights of those who produce and sell video games.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Professor Smith also argued a long list of voting rights cases in the Supreme Court.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Chambers USA has repeatedly named Professor Smith one of the country’s leading lawyers in appellate litigation, media and entertainment law, and First Amendment litigation for multiple years.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: In 2010, The National Law Journal named him one of the “Decade’s Most Influential Lawyers,” and the ABA Section of Civil Rights and Social Justice gave him its prestigious Thurgood Marshall Award for his work promoting civil rights and civil liberties.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: He has won similar awards from the American Constitution Society, the DC Bar, the Legal Aid Society of DC, the Electronic Privacy Information Center, and the Human Rights Campaign.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: In 2015 Professor Smith received an honorary degree from his alma mater, Amherst College.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: He is a board member and former President of the D.C. Bar Foundation, a Trustee of Amherst College, and a board member of EPIC, the Folger Shakespeare Library, and the Castleton Festival.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Professor Smith attended Yale Law School, where he was Editor-in-Chief of the Yale Law Journal, and then clerked for Judge James Oakes on the Second Circuit and Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr.
Name: Paul M. Smith

Value: Professor Snyder teaches constitutional law, constitutional history, and sports law.

Value: He has published law review articles in the Vanderbilt Law Review, Notre Dame Law Review, Law & History Review, UC-Davis Law Review, and Boston College Law Review.

Value: Prior to teaching at the University of Wisconsin Law School, Professor Snyder worked as an associate at Williams & Connolly LLP and wrote two critically acclaimed books about baseball including A Well-Paid Slave: Curt Flood’s Fight for Free Agency in Professional Sports(Viking/Penguin, 2006).

Value: A graduate of Duke University and Yale Law School, he clerked for the Hon. Dorothy W. Nelson on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

Value: He is the author of several books and articles concerning race and the constitutional concept of equality.

Value: He is currently a member of the American Law Institute.

Value: He has served on the Board of the D.C. Neighborhood Legal Services Program, and has been a Trustee of the D.C. Bar Client Security Fund.

Value: He has also served on the Board of Governors of the D.C. Bar, the Ethics Committee of the D.C. Bar, and the Administrative Conference of the United States.

Value: David P. Stewart teaches in the area of International and Transnational Law and co-directs the Global Law Scholars program and the Center for Transnational Business and the Law.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: He joined the faculty in 2008 following a career in the Office of the Legal Adviser, U.S. Department of State, where he served as Assistant Legal Adviser for Private International Law, Diplomatic Law and Litigation, African Affairs, Human Rights and Refugees, Law Enforcement and Intelligence, and International Claims and Investment Disputes, among other positions.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: He was previously in private practice at Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine in New York City.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: He also taught as an adjunct professor at the Law Center for over 25 years.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: He is past President and current Chair of the Board of Directors of the American Branch of the International Law Association and a member of the American Law Institute (co-Reporter for the Restatement (Fourth), Foreign Relations Law of the United States, published in 2018).
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: He serves on the Board of Editors of the American Journal of International Law and the Secretary of State’s Advisory Committee on Private International Law.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: In 2008 (and again in 2012) the OAS General Assembly elected him to serve on the Inter-American Juridical Committee.
Name: David P. Stewart

Value: Professor Jane Stromseth teaches and writes in the fields of constitutional law, justice and accountability for atrocity crimes, and international human rights.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: From 2013 to 2015, she served at the U.S. Department of State as Deputy to the Ambassador-at-Large in the Office of Global Criminal Justice and then as acting head of the office.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: She previously served in government as Senior Adviser on Rule of Law and International Humanitarian Policy at the Department of Defense, where she worked on establishment of the Atrocity Prevention Board; as Director for Multilateral and Humanitarian Affairs at the National Security Council; and as an Attorney-Adviser in the Office of the Legal Adviser at the Department of State.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: Dr. Stromseth has written widely on topics including post-conflict justice and rule of law building, humanitarian intervention, constitutional war powers, and international law and the use of force.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: She is co-author of Can Might Make Rights?
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: Building the Rule of Law After Military Interventions (2006); editor of Accountability for Atrocities: National and International Responses (2003); and author of The Origins of Flexible Response: NATO’s Debate over Strategy in the 1960s (1988); as well as numerous articles and book chapters.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: Prior to joining the Georgetown faculty, Dr. Stromseth served as a law clerk to U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O’Connor and to Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: Dr. Stromseth is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and a Counsellor of the American Society of International Law.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: She received her doctorate in International Relations at Oxford, where she was a Rhodes Scholar, and her law degree at Yale.
Name: Jane E. Stromseth

Value: Professor Stumberg is the author of recent work on government purchasing power and the impact of trade agreements on government authority.
Name: Robert K. Stumberg

Value: These include Turning a Blind Eye: Respecting Human Rights in Government Purchasing and Safeguards for Tobacco Control: Options for the TPPA.
Name: Robert K. Stumberg

Value: His previous work covered trade in services, legislation, economic development, community lending and housing policy.
Name: Robert K. Stumberg

Value: His past positions include service as Policy Director of the Center for Policy Alternatives in Washington, DC.
Name: Robert K. Stumberg

Value: He serves on the board of directors of the Center for the Study of Services, publisher of Consumer Checkbook magazines.

Value: Past service includes chairman of the AALS Section on Legislation;chairman of Susanna Wesley House;and board member of the Forum on Democracy and Trade;the Committee of 100 on the Federal City;the D.C. Housing Action Council;and the D.C. Mutual Housing Association.
Name: Robert K. Stumberg

Value: Neel U. Sukhatme is a Professor of Law at Georgetown University Law Center, an Andrew Carnegie Fellow for 2021–23, and the Thomas Alva Edison Visiting Scholar at the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Neel received his Ph.D. in Economics from Princeton University, where he was awarded the 2014 Towbes Prize for Outstanding Teaching.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: He received his J.D., cum laude, from Harvard Law School, where he served as Notes Editor of the Harvard Law Review.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: After law school, Neel clerked for the Hon. Vaughn R. Walker on the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California and the Hon. Ann Claire Williams on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Neel is licensed to practice law in Illinois (inactive) and California, and he previously worked at Latham & Watkins LLP.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: He received his Bachelor’s Degree in Computer Engineering (highest honors) with a minor in Mathematics from the University of Illinois.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Neel also co-founded Spindrop, a music technology and Internet radio startup with a novel approach for automatically mixing songs.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: In 2020, Neel co-founded Free Our Vote, a non-partisan, non-profit organization of data scientists, economists, and legal researchers that seeks to restore voting rights for former felons in Florida.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: These individuals are being denied their right to vote because they owe fines, fees, court costs, or restitution.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Working with its partner Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights, Free Our Vote paid off fines/fees for over 1,000 former felons in Florida in time for the November 2020 election.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Working with its partner the Campaign Legal Center, Free Our Vote also reached out to tens of thousands more, notifying them that they did not appear to owe disqualifying fines/fees and were therefore free to vote in the election.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Neel has published or forthcoming articles in the Harvard Law Review, Duke Law Journal, Cornell Law Review, Minnesota Law Review, American Law and Economics Review, International Review of Law and Economics, William & Mary Law Review, Washington and Lee Law Review, Houston Law Review, Harvard International Law Journal, The Regulatory Review, and Competition Policy International.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: His current research focuses on empirical patent law and law and economics.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: He teaches Property, Patent Law, Corporate Finance, Advanced Corporate Finance: Quantitative Analysis and Valuation, and Empirical Analysis for Lawyers and Policymakers, and he co-directs the Georgetown Law and Economics Workshop series.
Name: Neel U. Sukhatme

Value: Professor Sunder is a leading scholar of law and culture.
Name: Madhavi Sunder

Value: She was named a  Carnegie Scholar in 2006 and has been a Visiting Professor of Law at  the Yale Law School, the University of Chicago Law School, and Cornell  Law School.
Name: Madhavi Sunder

Value: Her work traverses numerous legal fields, from intellectual  property to human rights law and the First Amendment.
Name: Madhavi Sunder

Value: Professor Sunder  has published articles in the Yale Law Journal, the Stanford Law Review, the California Law Review, the Texas Law Review, and Law and Contemporary Problems,  among others.

Value: Her book, From Goods to a Good Life: Intellectual  Property and Global Justice, was published by Yale University Press in  2012.

Value: David A. Super’s research focuses on Administrative Law, Constitutional Law, Legislation (including the federal budget), Local Government Law, and Public Welfare Law.

Name: David A. Super

Value: In addition to Georgetown, he has also taught law at Columbia, Harvard, Howard, Maryland, Penn, Washington & Lee, and Yale.

Name: David A. Super

Value: He also was a recipient of the Frank F. Flegal Excellence in Teaching Award in 2018.
Name: David A. Super

Value: Professor Tague’s principal areas of expertise are evidence, criminal procedure, criminal law, and professional responsibility.
Name: Peter W. Tague

Value: Since joining the Law Center faculty in 1976, he has also served as the Scholar in Residence of Kings College in London, as visiting professor at the Universities of New South Wales and Melbourne and at New York University Law School, twice as visiting professor for San Diego Law School’s summer law programs in Oxford and in Dublin, and once for its program in Paris, twice at GULC’s Summer Law Program in Florence, and eight times as director of GULC’s summer program in London.
Name: Peter W. Tague

Value: He practiced law for over four years as a lawyer with the Public Defender’s Office in Alameda County, California and for two years with the San Francisco firm of Howard and Prim, and clerked for J. Walter Mansfield, then of the District Court in the Southern District of New York.
Name: Peter W. Tague

Value: He is active in the American Bar Association, having served as chair of the Committee on Defense Counsel Competency and as vice-chair of the Committees on Professional Responsibility and on Rules of Criminal Procedure and Evidence.
Name: Peter W. Tague

Value: He has published a book about the practice of criminal law by barristers in England, and numerous articles in the areas of professional ethics, evidence, and criminal defense.
Name: Peter W. Tague

Value: Professor Tatarowicz is a Professor in the Graduate Tax Program at Georgetown and Faculty Advisor of the State and Local Tax (SALT) Certificate Program.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: He is also Of Counsel at the law firm of Blank Rome LLP in Washington, D.C. Professor Tatarowicz has taught at the Law Center as an adjunct professor since 1984, and became a full-time professor in the Graduate Tax Program in 2011.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: Prior to joining the Law Center full-time, he served as the national leader of the State & Local Tax Practice at Ernst & Young LLP.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: He teaches and writes on issues that address multijurisdictional taxation, federal limitations on the powers of subnational governments to tax, the federal income taxation of partners and partnerships, as well as U.S. Tax Systems, Limitations and Policies, which he taught as a Visiting Professor of Law at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: Also, Professor Tatarowicz has served as faculty advisor to the Tax Lawyer and The State and Local Tax Lawer.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: And, since 1982 has chaired the Law Center’s Advanced State and Local Tax Institute.
Name: Philip M. Tatarowicz

Value: Joshua C. Teitelbaum is Professor of Law and Anne Fleming Research Professor at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: His research interests lie primarily in decision theory and related fields in microeconomics and their intersections with law and regulation.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: His work has appeared in the American Economic Review, Econometrica, the Journal of Legal Studies, and the Journal of Empirical Legal Studies, among other journals.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: He is co-editor of the Research Handbook in Behavioral Law and Economics, an Associate Editor of the International Review of Law and Economics, and a Fellow at the Georgetown Center for Economic Research.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: He previously served as the Associate Dean for Research and Academic Programs for the Law Center and as an Associate Editor of the Supreme Court Economic Review.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: Before coming to Georgetown in 2009, Professor Teitelbaum clerked for Judge Richard M. Berman of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, practiced corporate and securities law at Cahill Gordon & Reindel in New York, and was a Visiting Assistant Professor at Cornell Law School.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: He holds a Ph.D. in Economics from Cornell University and a J.D. from Harvard Law School.
Name: Joshua C. Teitelbaum

Value: Professor Thomas joined the Law Center faculty in 2002.
