Value: Professor Thompson teaches courses in the corporate and securities area, including mergers and limited liability.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: He joined the Georgetown faculty in 2010 after visiting in 2009-10.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: Previous positions include service as the New York Alumni Chancellor’s Professor of Law and Professor of Management at Vanderbilt University and the George Alexander Madill Professor of Law at Washington University.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: He has visited at New York University and Northwestern University and has taught intensive courses at the University of Sydney.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: He has authored or co-authored casebooks on corporations and on mergers, treatises on Close Corporations and Oppression of Minority Shareholders and LLC Members, and more than 50 articles.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: Professor Thompson has testified before committees of Congress, a state legislature, and the New York Stock Exchange.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: He has served since 1991 as editor of the Corporate Practice Commentator, served as an adviser for the American Law Institute’s Restatement (Third) of Agency and chaired two sections of the Association of American Law Schools.
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: 2012 List of Articles
Name: Robert B. Thompson

Value: After graduating from the Law Center, Professor Tiscione (then Robbins) joined the firm of Kirkland & Ellis in Washington, D.C. While at Kirkland & Ellis, she specialized in commerical litigation, including products liability and copyright infringement.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: Professor Tiscione taught Legal Research and Writing while still in practice at the George Washington University National Law Center and then came to Georgetown to teach full-time.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: Her scholarly interests include classical and contemporary rhetoric, the role of emotion in law, feminist jurisprudence, and empirical research in the current practice of law and its implications for legal pedagogy.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: She has served as an Editorial Board Member and Associate Editor of the Journal Of The Legal Writing Institute; a Director of the Association of Legal Writing Directors; an Affiliate Board Member of the Society of American Law Teachers; and a Director of the Legal Writing Institute (LWI), a national non-profit organization dedicated to improving legal communication, the teaching of legal writing, and the status of legal writing faculty nationwide.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: More recently, Tiscione has served as LWI’s President.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: Her areas of expertise are Legal Research and Writing and Law and Rhetoric.
Name: Kristen Konrad Tiscione

Value: Professor Tobia’s scholarship focuses on legal theory and interpretation, torts, health law and bioethics, and empirical legal studies.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: He teaches Torts and the Legal Justice Seminar and organizes meetings of the Georgetown Law & Language Lab, a research group in “experimental jurisprudence.”
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: That research uses empirical methods (especially ones from cognitive science) to help address questions traditionally associated with legal theory.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: He previously taught Legal Philosophy at Oxford and has assisted in the instruction of courses in Contracts, Contract Design, Health Law & Bioethics, Law & Economics, and Torts.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: Professor Tobia received a B.A., summa cum laude, in Philosophy, Mathematics, and Cognitive Science from Rutgers University; a B.Phil.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: (Philosophy M.A.) with distinction from Oxford as an Ertegun Scholar; and a J.D. and Ph.D. with distinction from Yale, as an Articles Editor of the Yale Law Journal and Editor-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities, Coker Teaching Fellow in Torts, and Prize Teaching Fellow in Philosophy.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: His scholarship has been awarded the Yale Law School Felix S. Cohen prize for legal philosophy and the AALS Section on Jurisprudence “Future Promise Award” for scholarship in legal philosophy, and it has appeared or is forthcoming in the Harvard Law Review, Yale Law Journal, University of Chicago Law Review, and Columbia Law Review and peer-reviewed journals including Analysis, Cognitive Science, the Journal of Nuclear Medicine, and Mind & Language.
Name: Kevin Tobia

Value: William M. Treanor is the Dean and Executive Vice President of Georgetown University Law Center, and he holds the Law Center’s Paul Regis Dean Leadership Professorship.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Dean Treanor joined Georgetown in 2010 and was reappointed to serve a third term beginning July 1, 2020.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Under Treanor’s leadership, Georgetown Law has hired 51 new faculty members; tripled the number of experiential offerings for students in its clinical, externship, and practicum programs; and experienced its most successful era of fundraising, culminating in nearly $56 million in annual giving in 2021.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: As dean, Treanor has worked to advance Georgetown Law’s commitment to affordability and access.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: During his tenure, Georgetown has more than doubled financial aid; raised nearly $20 million dollars for the Law Center’s scholarship program for exceptional students with significant financial need; and launched the RISE program, which provides academic support for students from historically underrepresented groups.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: The Law Center also created the Early Outreach Initiative which brings the Law Center’s dean of admissions, current law students, and alumni into urban high schools across the country to encourage student interest in pursuing careers as lawyers.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Georgetown Law’s motto is “Law is but the means; justice is the end,” and Treanor has focused on increasing opportunities for students to pursue careers in public interest law.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: The newly-established Blume Public Interest Leaders program provides full tuition scholarships, mentors, and specialized programs to a select group of students who wish to pursue careers in the public interest area.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: The Law Center has also initiated a program of post-graduate fellowships that have enabled more than 100 graduates to work in public interest jobs, and, in combination with the law firms Arent Fox and DLA Piper, it has launched the DC Affordable Law Firm, a “low bono” law firm where recent Georgetown Law graduates provide legal representation to people of limited means.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Dean Treanor has worked to develop Georgetown Law’s world-class program in law and technology.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Currently, the Law Center has 15 faculty experts in law and technology and offers 85 courses in this area.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: During the dean’s tenure, the Law Center has established the Institute for Technology Law & Policy; the Center on Privacy & Technology; the Technology Scholars Program; and the Georgetown Law Technology Review.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: In 2012, Dean Treanor was recognized by the National Law Journal as a “Champion” because of his work to “uphold the profession’s core values.”
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: In the same year, he received the 2012 David Stoner Uncommon Counselor Award from the David Nee Foundation for his efforts to raise mental health awareness among law students.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: National Jurist magazine has named him one of the most influential people in legal education four times.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: He is a member of the Morristown (N.J.) High School Hall of Fame.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Most recently, in 2020 he was elected into the American Academy of Arts & Sciences for law and education.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Treanor’s areas of academic expertise include constitutional law, property law, criminal law, intellectual property, and legal history.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: At Georgetown Law, he has taught a first-year legal justice seminar, an upper-level course on the drafting of the U.S. Constitution, and most recently leadership courses.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: His writings have principally been in the area of constitutional history, and he has been recognized as one of the 10 most-cited legal history scholars in the United States by the University of Chicago Law School’s Brian Leiter.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: His early work largely focused on the history of constitutional protections of private property.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: His articles were selected three times by the Land Use and Environment Law Review as among the year’s finest, and his article “The Original Understanding of the Takings Clause and the Political Process,” 95 Colum. L. Rev. 782 (1995), was recently recognized by the Land Use Professors Blog as the most cited land use article of the past 30 years.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Treanor’s more recent work, including “Judicial Review before Marbury,” his doctoral dissertation, has focused on the emergence of judicial review and on constitutional interpretation in the early republic.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: His forthcoming article, “The Case of the Dishonest Scrivener: Gouverneur Morris and the Creation of the Federalist Constitution,” a study of the changes that constitutional convention delegate Gouverneur Morris and the Committee of Style made in preparing the Constitution’s final draft, will be published in the October 2021 issue of the Michigan Law Review.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Before coming to Georgetown, Treanor was Dean and Paul Fuller Professor of Law at Fordham Law School, where he began teaching in 1991.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: He also has served in a variety of positions in the government, including Deputy Assistant Attorney General in the Office of Legal Counsel, U.S. Department of Justice; Associate Counsel, Office of Independent Counsel during the Iran/Contra investigation; Speechwriter to the United States Secretary of Education; Special Assistant U.S. Attorney in the District of Columbia United States Attorney’s Office; and Special Assistant to the Chair of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: He was law clerk to the Honorable James L. Oakes, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Treanor has a Ph.D. in history from Harvard University, a J.D. from Yale Law School, and a B.A. from Yale College (summa cum laude).
Name: William M. Treanor

Value: Philomila Tsoukala is a Professor of Law at Georgetown Law.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: Her research interests focus on the position of family law in the political economy of western liberal states, with a special emphasis on the gendered character of family and market regulation.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: She teaches in the areas of family law, European Union law and legal theory.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: She has written extensively about the recent European crisis from the perspective of family regulation and welfare law, warning about the permanent transformation of the European Union through crisis management.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: Her 2015 article Household Regulation and European Integration: The Family Portrait of a Crisis, 63 Am. J. Comp. L. 747-799,won the Yntema Prize from the American Society of Comparative Law.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: She is co-editor, along with Professors Areen and Spindelman, of a major Family Law casebook.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: Professor Tsoukala has also written about the use of family law in the construction of national identities, critically engaging with recent projects of family law harmonization in Europe.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: In the past, her work has emphasized the importance of engaging with economic analyses of gender in order to properly understand gendered phenomena in the family and the market.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: Professor Tsoukala was previously a Visiting Associate Professor at GULC, a Visiting Assistant Professor (Emerging Scholars Program) at the University of Texas School of Law (Emerging Scholars Program), and a Byse Fellow at Harvard Law School.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: She has a SJD from Harvard Law School, a master’s degree from Paris II, Panthéon-Assas, and a LLB from Aristotle University of Thessaloniki.
Name: Philomila Tsoukala

Value: After graduating from law school, where he was Articles and Book Reviews Editor of the Columbia Law Review, Professor Vazquez served as a law clerk to the Honorable Stephen Reinhardt of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Name: Carlos Manuel Vazquez

Value: He then practiced law with Covington and Burling in Washington, DC, before joining the law school faculty as a visiting professor of law in 1990, and then as an associate professor in 1991.
Name: Carlos Manuel Vazquez

Value: From 2000 to 2003, he was the United States member of the Inter-American Juridical Committee, the organ of the Organization of American States responsible for juridical matters and for promoting the progressive development and codification of international law in the Americas.
Name: Carlos Manuel Vazquez

Value: Professor Vazquez has written and taught primarily in the areas of international law, constitutional law, and federal courts.
Name: Carlos Manuel Vazquez

Value: Urska Velikonja is a Professor of Law at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Before joining the Georgetown faculty in 2017, Professor Velikonja taught at Emory University and the University of Maryland, and visited at UC Berkeley, the University of Chicago and Duke Law School.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: She graduated first in her class at University of Ljubljana School of Law and earned her LL.M. and J.D. magna cum laude from Harvard Law School.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Prior to entering academia, Professor Velikonja clerked for Judge Stephen F. Williams of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit and worked for several years as a banking and finance associate and cross-border M&A with an Austrian law in her native Slovenia.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Professor Velikonja has written extensively on securities regulation and securities enforcement.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Her work has been published by the California Law Review, the Cornell Law Review, the Notre Dame Law Review, the Stanford Law Review, the Washington University Law Review, the Yale Law Journal, and the Yale Journal on Regulation, among others.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Her article on SEC fair funds was selected as one of top ten articles published in 2015, and two of her articles were selected for presentation at the Harvard-Stanford-Yale Junior Faculty Forum.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Professor Velikonja’s work on SEC enforcement is regularly discussed by regulators and has been featured in exclusive and/or major stories in the Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, the New York Times, and The Economist, and quoted in the Financial Times, Reuters, The American Banker, as well as international press.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Professor Velikonja also regularly contributes to three corporate law and financial regulation law blogs: the Harvard Law School Corporate Governance and Financial Regulation Forum, the NYU PCCE Compliance & Enforcement Blog, and the Columbia Law School Blue Sky Blog.
Name: Urska Velikonja

Value: Professor Vladeck teaches civil procedure, federal courts, a practicum on privacy and technology (taught jointly with MIT), and directs the Civil Litigation Clinic, a student clinic that handles trial court litigation focused on public-interest cases.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: He also serves as Faculty Director of the Law Center’s Center on Privacy and Technology.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: From 2002 to 2009, Professor Vladeck served as Director of the Civil Rights section of Georgetown Law’s Institute for Public Representation, a student clinic that handles complex trial court and appellate litigation focused on civil rights and other public-interest litigation, while also teaching civil procedure and federal courts.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: From 2009 to 2012, Professor Vladeck took leave from Georgetown to serve as the Director of the Federal Trade Commission’s Bureau of Consumer Protection.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: At the FTC, he supervised the Bureau’s 450 lawyers, investigators, paralegals and support staff in carrying out the Bureau’s work to protect consumers from unfair, deceptive or fraudulent practices.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: Before joining the Law Center faculty full-time in 2002, Professor Vladeck spent over 25 years with Public Citizen Litigation Group, a national public interest law firm, serving the last ten years as the Group’s director.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: He has briefed and argued a number of cases before the U.S. Supreme Court and more than sixty cases before federal courts of appeal and state courts of last resort.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: He is a Senior Fellow of the Administrative Conference of the United States and an elected member of the American Law Institute.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: He also serves on the Board of Trustees of the Natural Resources Defense Council and on the Board of the National Consumers Law Center.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: Professor Vladeck frequently testifies before Congress and writes on administrative law, First Amendment, consumer protection, privacy, and access to justice issues.
Name: David C. Vladeck

Value: Professor Brown Weiss is highly active in the areas of public international, environmental, and water resources law.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: In September 2002 she was appointed to a 5-year term on the 3-member Inspection Panel of the World Bank and from 2003-2007 served full-time as the Chairperson of the Inspection Panel, an appointment at the Vice-Presidential level.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Since January 2012, she has served as a Judge on the International Monetary Fund’s Administrative Tribunal.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: She has been a Judge on the Inter-American Development Bank’s Administrative Tribunal from 2014 – 2020 and was President of the Tribunal in 2018.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Professor Brown Weiss is also a member of the nine person United Nations Environment Programme’s International Advisory Council on Environmental Justice.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Her past professional experience includes positions as Associate General Counsel for International Activities at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 1990-92, Assistant Professor of Civil Engineering and Politics at Princeton University, and Research Associate at Columbia University and the Brookings Institution.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Her numerous professional activities have included positions as President of the American Society of International Law, April 1994-96, U.S. Special Legal Advisor to the North American Commission on the Environment 1996-2002, chair of the Committee for Research on Global Environmental Change of the Social Science Research Council, 1989-94, and elected member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the American Law Institute, and the Commission on Environmental Law of the IUCN.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: She has been a member of the National Academy of Science’s Commission on Geosciences, Environment and Resources, NAS Water Science and Technology Board, the NAS, Israel, Jordan, Palestinian Territories Panel on Sustainable Water Supplies in the Middle East, and the NAS Environmental Studies Board.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: She served on the Board of Directors of the Japanese Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, the Council of Advisors to the Cousteau Society, the Board of Trustees for the Center for International Environmental Law, and the Advisory Council of the National Center for Atmospheric Research.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Professor Brown Weiss is a member of the Board of Editors of the American Journal of International Law; the Journal of International Economic Law; the Max Planck Encyclopedia of Public International Law; the Max Planck Encyclopedia of International Procedural Law; the Indian Journal of International Law; Transnational Environmental Law Journal; International Environmental Agreements: Politics, Law and Economics; and is faculty adviser to the Georgetown Environmental Law Review.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: She is the author of many articles and books, including Establishing Norms in a Kaleidoscopic World (2018), International Law for a Water-Scarce World (2013), Reconciling Environment and Trade (with Nathalie Bernasconi-Osterwalder and John Jackson, 2d. ed., 2008), International Environmental Law and Policy (co-author, 1998, 2007), Engaging Countries: Strengthening Compliance with International Accords (co-author, 1998) and In Fairness to Future Generations: International Law, Common Patrimony, and Intergenerational Equity (1989), which received the Certificate of Merit Award in 1990 from the American Society of International Law, and has been published in French, Japanese, Spanish, and Chinese.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: In July 2017, Professor Brown Weiss presented the General Course on Public International Law at The Hague Academy of International Law.
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: In 2010, Professor Brown Weiss received the Manley O. Hudson Medal from the American Society of International Law, in 2008 the Award for International Environmental Law from the Center for International Environmental Law, in 2003 the American Bar Association (ABA) Award for Distinguished Achievement in Environmental Law and Policy, in 1996 the Prominent Women in International Law Award from the American Society of International Law, and in 1994 the Elizabeth Haub Prize for international environmental law given by the Free University of Brussels and the International Council of Environmental Law (ICEL).
Name: Edith Brown Weiss

Value: Professor Dr. Franz Werro shares his life between the Faculté de droit of the University of Fribourg (Switzerland) and Georgetown Law, in Washington, DC.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He teaches and researches in different fields of private law, including the law of obligations, European private law and comparative law.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He was a visiting professor at the Cornell Law School (Ithaca, NY) and at a number of European Law schools, including the Universita degli Studi di Trieste (Italy), the Scuola Superiore Santa Anna in Pisa (Italy), the University of Pau (France), the University of Bordeaux (France), the International University College of Torino (Italy), the Bucerius Law School in Hamburg (Germany), the Sorbonne in Paris (France), the Tel-Aviv University (Israel) and Hebrew University (Israel).
Name: Franz Werro

Value: In addition, Professor Werro acts as an arbitrator and as a consultant in Swiss and in international commercial disputes.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He is on the board of a number of Swiss and European law journals and is involved in different projects of continuing legal education in Switzerland.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He has recently published a number of essays on various topics, including the Swiss law of obligations, the impact of EU law on national private law, as well as articles on comparative and transnational legal studies.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He just published the third edition of his treatise on tort law.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: Professor Werro taught as a visiting professor at the Georgetown University Law Center in the fall semesters of 1999 and 2000.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: He has been a permanent member of the faculty at Georgetown Law since 2001.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: In January 2014, Franz Werro, together with McGill Professor Helge Dedek, has become one of the Co-Editors-in-Chiefs of the American Journal of Comparative Law.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: For the year 2015/2016, Professor Werro was a co-director for Georgetown Law’s Center for Transnational Legal Studies, in London.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: In January 2020, the Swiss Federal Council appointed Professor Werro as the chair of the board of the Swiss Institute of Comparative Law.
Name: Franz Werro

Value: Since 2001, Professor Westmoreland has taught at Georgetown about health law, about federal budgets, and about legislation.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: Prior to that, he was the senior policy fellow at the Federal Legislation Clinic.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: He has worked extensively on public health and health finance policy.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: He has served as Counsel to the Subcommittee on Health and the Environment in the U.S. House of Representatives and later as the Director of the Medicaid program at HHS.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: Outside of government, he served as counsel to the Advisory Committee on Tobacco Policy and Public Health and as an advisor to both the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: He has been the recipient of a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Investigator in Health Policy Award, working on budget process and health policy.
Name: Timothy M. Westmoreland

Value: Jessica
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: Wherry teaches legal research and writing courses to first-year and upper-level students.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: Prior to joining Georgetown’s faculty, Professor Wherry was associate professor of legal research and writing, associate director of the legal research and writing program, and co-director of the scholarly writing program at The George Washington University Law School.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: Previously, she served as assistant counsel in the U.S. Department of the Navy’s Office of the General Counsel and as a cryptologic technician in the U.S. Navy.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: She earned an undergraduate degree from Lawrence University, a master of social science from Syracuse University, and a J.D. from the George Washington University Law School.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: She also earned a Certificate in Military & Veterans Health, Policy and Advocacy from William & Mary Law School.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: Professor Wherry’s primary scholarly interests are veterans and military law, and legal writing and rhetoric.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: She does pro bono work through the Homeless Persons Representation Project, assisting veterans with disability compensation claims and discharge upgrades.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: She also serves as Reporter to the Standing Committee on Maryland Pattern Jury Instructions-Civil and as co-managing editor to Legal Communication & Rhetoric: JALWD, the peer-reviewed flagship journal of the Association of Legal Writing Directors.
Name: Jessica L. Wherry

Value: Anne Marie Whitesell is Professor, LL.M. Program and Faculty Director, Program on International Arbitration and Dispute Resolution.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: Ms. Whitesell has practised with law firms in both the United States and in France, and has acted as arbitrator and counsel in numerous international arbitration cases.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: She was Secretary General of the ICC International Court of Arbitration from 2001 to 2007.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: She also previously taught at the Université de Paris I and the Institut de Droit Comparé.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: She serves as a member of various boards and committees related to dispute resolution and is the Director of the Alternative Dispute Resolution Center of the International Law Institute.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: Ms. Whitesell received her A.B. from Smith College, her J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law and her Doctorate in Law from the Université de Paris I, Panthéon-Sorbonne.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: She is admitted to the New York State Bar, the District of Columbia Bar and the US District Courts for the Southern and Eastern Districts of New York.
Name: Anne Marie Whitesell

Value: Professor Williams received her J.D. from Stanford Law School and her Ph.D. in Sociology from Stanford.
Name: Jamillah Bowman Williams

Value: Her research focuses on contemporary bias, the effectiveness of antidiscrimination law, and the capacity of law to promote compliance and social change.
Name: Jamillah Bowman Williams

Value: More specifically, she uses social psychological theory and empirical analysis to examine the impact of antidiscrimination law on the individuals it was intended to protect.
Name: Jamillah Bowman Williams

Value: After law school, Dr. Williams worked as an Associate in the Employment Law practice of Paul Hastings, LLP in Chicago, IL where she specialized in conducting privileged diagnostics of employment processes and advising employers on diversity/inclusion programs.
Name: Jamillah Bowman Williams

Value: Before joining the faculty at Georgetown University Law Center, Williams was a National Science Foundation Fellow and Visiting Scholar at the American Bar Foundation in Chicago, IL.
Name: Jamillah Bowman Williams

Value: David Wishnick is an Associate Professor at Georgetown Law, where he specializes in financial regulation and contract law.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: His research focuses on interactions between law and technology in shaping financial markets, firms, and transactional forms.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: His work has appeared in publications including the Columbia Law Review, Minnesota Law Review, and Yale Law Journal.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: Before joining the faculty, David held a fellowship at the University of Pennsylvania Law School’s Center for Technology, Innovation, and Competition and practiced law in the Washington, D.C., office of Jenner & Block.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: While in practice, he advised clients in the finance and communications industries and, in a multiyear engagement, participated in the monitorship of a large bank after its settlement with tax and securities regulators.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: He began his law career by serving as a clerk on the D.C. Circuit to Judge Thomas Griffith and on the Second Circuit to Judge Guido Calabresi.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: David received his law degree from Yale Law School and his undergraduate degree from Brown University.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: He was born and raised in Chicago.
Name: David A. Wishnick

Value: Professor Wolfman re-joined the Georgetown Law faculty in 2016 as the Director of the new full-time, semester-long Appellate Courts Immersion Clinic.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: He was previously a Professor of the Practice of Law and Co-Director of Stanford Law School’s Supreme Court Litigation Clinic.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Before that, from 2009 to 2014, Professor Wolfman served as Director of the Civil Rights section of Georgetown Law’s Institute for Public Representation, a student clinic that handles complex trial court and appellate litigation focused on civil rights and other public-interest litigation.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: While at Georgetown, he also taught the standard doctrinal course on Federal Courts and the Federal System and a course on appellate courts.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Before Georgetown, he spent nearly 20 years at the national public interest law firm Public Citizen Litigation Group, serving the last five years as the Group’s Director.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Earlier in his career, he conducted trial and appellate litigation as a staff lawyer at a rural poverty law program in Arkansas.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Professor Wolfman has handled a broad range of litigation, including cases involving health and safety regulation, class action governance, court-access issues, federal preemption, consumer law, public-benefits law, and government transparency.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: He has argued six cases before the Supreme Court (winning five), and he has litigated hundreds of cases before federal and state appellate and trial courts around the country.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: He directed Public Citizen’s Supreme Court Assistance Project, which helps “underdog” public-interest clients litigate before the U.S. Supreme Court.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: He has testified before Congress and federal rules committees on a range of issues, and he was an Advisor to the American Law Institute’s Principles of the Law of Aggregate Litigation.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Since 2004, he has taught an intensive Appellate Courts Workshop during the January Term at Harvard Law School.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Professor Wolfman has authored articles on a variety of subjects, often on the intersection of state tort law and federal preemption doctrine and on class actions.
Name: Brian Wolfman

Value: Professor Abell has been a partner at Furey, Doolan & Abell since 1975.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: He specializes in estate planning and non-profit organizations.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: Prior to that, he was executive assistant to the Maryland Lieutenant Governor and Governor, as well as Secretary of the Maryland Department of Employment and Social Services.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: He has served on the boards of several foundations, especially focusing on homelessness.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: He has also been active in a number of religious and social justice organizations, including the Initiative on Catholic Social Thought and Public Life at Georgetown.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: Professor Abell has been an adjunct professor at GULC since 1985, teaching Judicial Philosophy of the Supreme Court Seminar, Professional Responsibility, the Estate Planning Seminar, and The Practicing Lawyer and the Poor.
Name: W. Shepherdson Abell

Value: Alvaro Bedoya is the Founding Director of the Center on Privacy & Technology at Georgetown Law, where he is also a Visiting Professor of Law.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: He established the Privacy Center in 2014 with a focus on exposing and countering the “the color of surveillance” – surveillance’s disparate impact on people of color, immigrants, and other historically marginalized people.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: In 2016, he co-authored The Perpetual Line-Up: Unregulated Police Face Recognition in America, a year-long investigation that revealed that most American adults are enrolled in a police face recognition network, and that vendor companies were doing little to address the race and gender bias endemic to face scanning software.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: Alvaro is also the creator of the Immigrant Surveillance Working Group, a coalition of digital and immigrant rights organizations.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: He has testified before Congress and state legislatures, and his writing has appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Atlantic and Slate.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: Before founding the Center, Alvaro served as Chief Counsel of the U.S. Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology and the Law, where he conducted oversight on mobile location privacy and biometrics, and drafted portions of the 2015 NSA reform legislation, the USA FREEDOM Act.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: In 2009, he co-founded the Esperanza Education Fund, an immigration status-blind college scholarship for immigrant students that has awarded over $1 million to high school seniors in the District of Columbia, Maryland, and Virginia.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: A naturalized citizen born in Peru and raised in upstate New York, Alvaro graduated summa cum laude from Harvard College and holds a J.D. from Yale Law School, where he served on the Yale Law Journal and received the Paul & Daisy Soros Fellowship for New Americans.
Name: Alvaro Bedoya

Value: Marta Beresin is a Visiting Professor of Law in Georgetown Law Center’s Health Justice Alliance Law Clinic.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Throughout her legal career, Professor Beresin has worked at the intersection of child welfare and family homelessness.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: At the Washington Legal Clinic for the Homeless, Professor Beresin represented homeless families in shelter, housing, disability rights, and public benefits cases, and advocated locally for budget and policy initiatives to serve her clients’ interests such as affordable housing and a more robust TANF program.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: She also trained and supervised pro bono attorneys and engaged in community education, outreach, and organizing of shelter residents to assist their efforts to create a more just, respectful, and supportive homeless services continuum of care in Washington, DC.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Early in her career, Professor Beresin represented children in child abuse and neglect cases and parents experiencing homelessness in family law matters.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Most recently, she served as the Legal and Policy Director for Break the Cycle, a national non-profit focused on teen dating violence, where she created a partnership with two DC school-based health centers to screen and refer high school students in need of protection orders and related legal matters.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Professor Beresin has testified before the DC Council and Congress and provided commentary related to family homelessness on Pacifica Radio, NPR Morning Edition, and other news outlets.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: She has spoken at national conferences and Symposiums and written about the devastating impact of the separation of children from their families due to housing insecurity and homelessness.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Professor Beresin received her J.D. with honors from George Washington University Law School and a B.A. in Political Science from Penn State University.
Name: Marta Beresin

Value: Andrew Blair-Stanek’s research and teaching interest is tax law.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: He draws from non-tax scholarship and case law to improve and to better understand tax law.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: Prior to joining the UM Carey Law Faculty, Professor Blair-Stanek practiced tax law at McDermott, Will & Emery, LLP in Washington, DC.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: His practice included bankruptcy taxation, intellectual property transactions, cross-border mergers, international tax planning, and real estate investment trust formation.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: Prior to practice, he clerked in Baltimore for the Hon. Paul V. Niemeyer, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: Professor Blair-Stanek received his undergraduate degree in mathematics, summa cum laude, from Princeton University, and his JD from Yale Law School, where he was on the Yale Law Journal.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: Before attending law school, he worked as a software design engineer for Microsoft Corporation and is the inventor of U.S. Patents 7,617,204 and 7,580,951.
Name: Andrew Blair-Stanek

Value: Heather Bock, Ph.D. is the Chief Professional Development Officer for Hogan Lovells US LLP and oversees associate and partner training and development.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: She facilitates learning and development initiatives across the firm and is responsible for enhancing the people development tools and processes.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: Prior to joining Hogan Lovells, she managed the training and development function for other professional services firms including Howrey LLP and Andersen.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: She also consulted to a variety of companies on HR strategy, organizational transformation and culture change.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: Heather’s training initiatives won the NALP Award of Distinction and the Association of Training and Development (ASTD) BEST Award.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: In addition, Heather received the HR Leadership Award of Greater Washington in 2006 and the Chief Learning Officer Vanguard Award in 2007.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: She has written several articles and authored a book on Using a Competency Model to Manage Firm Talent for the American Bar Association.
Name: Heather E. Bock

Value: Stephen B. Bright is visiting professor of law at Georgetown and a visiting lecturer at Yale Law School.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: He spent 35 years at the Southern Center for Human Rights in Atlanta, first as director for 22 years and then as president and senior counsel through 2016.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: He has tried capital cases to juries in Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi, and argued and won four capital cases before the Supreme Court.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: Before joining the Center, he was a trial attorney at the Public Defender Service in Washington, DC, and a legal services attorney at the Appalachian Research & Defense Fund of Kentucky.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: He was also director of Law Students in Court, a clinical program operated by a consortium of law schools in Washington.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: Subjects of his litigation, teaching and writings include capital punishment, legal representation of poor people accused of crimes, racial discrimination in the criminal legal system, conditions and practices in prisons and jails, and judicial independence.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: He received the American Bar Association’s Thurgood Marshall Award in 1998.
Name: Stephen Bright

Value: Dorothy A. Brown is Asa Griggs Candler Professor of Law at Emory University School of Law and an advocate for economic and social justice.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She is the author of THE WHITENESS OF WEALTH: HOW THE TAX SYSTEM IMPOVERISHES BLACK AMERICANS- AND HOW WE CAN FIX IT (Crown 3/23/2021).
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She is well known for her work in a variety of areas: the effects of tax policy by race, class, and/or gender; workplace equity and inclusion; and law school reform.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She is also the author of the path breaking CRITICAL RACE THEORY: CASES, MATERIALS AND PROBLEMS currently in its third edition, which applies a racial lens to foundational law school courses such as contracts, property, civil and criminal law and procedure.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She is a co-author of Federal Income Taxation: Cases, Problems, and Materials (West Academic Publishing, Sixth and Seventh editions).
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She has appeared on CNN, MSNBC, and Bloomberg, and has written numerous opinion pieces addressing current events in the New York Times, The Atlantic, CNN Opinion, Washington Post, Forbes, National Law Journal and Bloomberg View to name a few.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: Currently Dorothy teaches Fundamentals of Income Tax, Legislation and Regulation, Corporate Tax, Critical Race Theory and Tax Policy.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: She has won teaching awards at every law school she has taught.
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: In 2018 she was co-recipient of the Clyde Ferguson Award 2018 (awarded by the AALS Minority Groups Section to outstanding law teachers who in the course of their careers have achieved excellence in the areas of public service, teaching and scholarship).
Name: Dorothy Brown

Value: Gian Luca Burci was named Adjunct Professor at the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies of Geneva in 2012.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: He served in the Legal Office of the World Health Organization since 1998 and was its Legal Counsel from April 2005 until its retirement in February 2016.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Professor Burci previously served as Legal Officer at the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna in 1998-1999 and in the Office of the Legal Counsel of the United Nations in New York for nearly a decade.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: At the Graduate Institute he teaches international health law within the framework of the joint LLM in Global Health Law and International Institutions Programme in partnership with Georgetown University, as well as a course on the law and practice of the United Nations.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Among other professional achievements, he was closely involved in the negotiation and implementation of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and its Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, the revision and implementation of the International Health Regulations (2005), WHO’s response to the 2014-2016 Ebola outbreak and WHO reform.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Prof.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Burci holds a post graduate degree in law from the Università degli Studi di Genova, Italy.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: His areas of expertise are public international law, the law of international organizations as well as global health governance and law.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Prof. Burci is the co-author of the leading English book on WHO, editor of the first research collection on global health law, co-editor and contributor to the first research handbook on global health law, and author of numerous articles and book chapters.
Name: Gian Luca Burci

Value: Oscar A. Cabrera, Abogado (JD equivalent), LL.M., is the Director of the O’Neill Institute for National and Global Health Law and an Adjunct Professor of Law at Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: Previously, Professor Cabrera served as the Deputy Director of the O’Neill Institute from 2009-2011.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: He is a foreign-trained attorney who earned his law degree in his home country of Venezuela, and his Master of Laws (LL.M.), with concentration in Health Law and Policy, at the University of Toronto.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: Before starting his Masters Degree program, Professor Cabrera worked as an Associate at a Venezuelan law firm (d’Empaire Reyna Bermúdez).
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: Professor Cabrera was awarded a Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) Health Law and Policy Fellowship for his Masters program.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: After earning his LL.M., he worked as a Research Associate with Professor Colleen Flood, at the University of Toronto, Faculty of Law and the Institute of Health Services and Policy Research (CIHR-IHSPR).
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: In this capacity, he was involved in several health law related projects.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: Professor Cabrera has worked on projects with the World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, among other organizations.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: He has studied and is interested in various health law related fields, such as public health law, sexual and reproductive rights, health and human rights, global tobacco litigation and health systems law and policy.
Name: Oscar Cabrera

Value: Sara Colangelo is the Director of the Environmental Law & Justice Clinic and a Visiting Professor of Law.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: She is the 2020 recipient of the Georgetown Law Fahy Teaching Award.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: From 2015-2021 Professor Colangelo served as the Director of Georgetown’s Environmental Law and Policy Program, teaching multiple courses in environmental law.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Her areas of specialty are environmental litigation and enforcement, including community considerations in the enforcement process:
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: She speaks at conferences, appears in the media, and provides Congressional testimony on these topics.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Professor Colangelo is a member of multiple boards and committees on environmental law and scholarship, science and health, and environmental justice.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Previously Professor Colangelo served as a trial attorney for the Environmental Enforcement Section (EES) of the Environment and Natural Resources Division at the Department of Justice for many years.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: She joined the Division through the Attorney General’s Honors Program.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: At EES, she managed complex civil environmental enforcement cases for pollution control and cleanup of hazardous waste sites to negotiated or litigated resolution, appearing on behalf of the United States in trials across the country.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Professor Colangelo received multiple awards from the Environmental Protection Agency and from the Environment Division for her work.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: In addition, she was nominated for two awards from the Attorney General.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Professor Colangelo graduated cum laude from Georgetown Law, where she was a research assistant to Professor Richard Lazarus, worked in the environmental section of the Institute for Public Representation Clinic, and served on the Georgetown International Environmental Law Review.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: She was inducted into Phi Beta Kappa and received the William Gaston Premium Scholarship at Brown University, where she graduated magna cum laude with a B.A. in International Relations on the Global Environment Track.
Name: Sara Colangelo

Value: Anupama Chaturvedi Connor is a Visiting Associate Professor of Law in Legal Practice.
Name: Anupama Connor

Value: Prior to joining the faculty, Professor Connor helped manage a new model virtual law firm, Potomac Law Group, from its early start-up phase to the robust firm it is currently.
Name: Anupama Connor

Value: Before that, she advised the Chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission as a Senior Counsel helping advance the agency’s mission to keep individuals safe from unreasonable risks of injury and death from consumer products.
Name: Anupama Connor

Value: Earlier in her career she was an associate practicing civil litigation at Debevoise & Plimpton LLP in Washington, D.C. and Perkins Coie LLP in Denver, Colorado.
Name: Anupama Connor

Value: Professor Connor received her J.D. cum laude, from Georgetown University Law Center in 2002 and her B.A. in Human Development from Cornell University in 1997.
Name: Anupama Connor

Value: Sara Kaiser Creighton is a Visiting Associate Professor of Law in Legal Practice.
Name: Sara Kaiser Creighton

Value: Most recently, Professor Creighton served as the Deputy Chief Counsel at American Oversight, a non-profit organization focused on government transparency and accountability.
Name: Sara Kaiser Creighton

Value: Before that, she worked as a litigator at Williams & Connolly LLP, where she specialized in complex civil litigation, including pharmaceutical patent litigation and other matters.
Name: Sara Kaiser Creighton

Value: Professor Creighton clerked for Chief Judge Sharon Prost of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
Name: Sara Kaiser Creighton

Value: Professor Creighton received her J.D., magna cum laude, from Georgetown University Law Center in 2010, and a B.A. in Human Biology from Stanford University.
Name: Sara Kaiser Creighton

Value: Michael Dreeben serves as a distinguished lecturer from government.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: From 1988 through 2019, Dreeben served in the Office of Solicitor General in the U.S. Department of Justice, first as an Assistant to the Solicitor General and then as a Deputy Solicitor General.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: As Deputy Solicitor General from 1994 to 2019, Dreeben supervised the criminal docket for the United States in the U.S. Supreme Court.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: Dreeben has argued 105 Supreme Court cases on behalf of the United States and briefed hundreds of other cases in the Supreme Court and in the lower federal courts.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: He also argued cases in every regional federal court of appeals, including en banc cases in ten circuits.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: In June of 2017, Dreeben was detailed to Office of Special Counsel Robert S. Mueller III where he served counselor to the special counsel in the investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and obstruction of justice.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: In that capacity, he successfully represented the special counsel’s office in federal court against legal challenges to its authority.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: During his tenure in the Solicitor General’s office, Dreeben argued many landmark cases in criminal law and procedure.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: These include cases involving hate crimes and the First Amendment, Fourth Amendment rights in the internet age, cases involving public corruption and private fraud, and the Sixth Amendment’s Confrontation Clause.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: For several months in 2006, he also served as a Special Assistant United States Attorney in the District of Maryland.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: Dreeben received his bachelor’s degree from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, a master’s degree in history from the University of Chicago, and his law degree from Duke University, where he served as an articles editor on the Duke Law Journal.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: He served as a law clerk to the honorable Jerre S. Williams of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: He has previously served as an adjunct professor at Georgetown Law and a visiting professor at Duke Law School, where he taught appellate advocacy and a seminar on constitutional litigation in the Supreme Court.
Name: Michael Dreeben

Value: Douglas Emhoff is a Distinguished Visitor from Practice at Georgetown Law and a Distinguished Fellow of Georgetown Law’s Institute for Technology Law and Policy.
Name: Douglas Emhoff

Value: In his almost 30 year career, Emhoff was known for tackling and resolving the toughest problems – whether by litigating high-stakes cases or acting as a trusted advisor in complex disputes with an emphasis on media, entertainment, and Intellectual Property matters.
Name: Douglas Emhoff

Value: Emhoff is a devoted father and proud husband.
Name: Douglas Emhoff

Value: B.S., J.D., Georgetown.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Professor Eduardo “Eddie” Ferrer is DCLY’s Legal & Policy Director as well as a founding member and former Executive Director of the organization.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Professor Ferrer also serves as the Chair of the Board of Directors of the Campaign for Youth Justice and the Chair of the Board of Trustees of The Next Step Charter School in Columbia Heights.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Professor Ferrer was a member of the 2012-13 class of the Nonprofit Roundtable of Greater Washington’s Future Executive Director Program and served as the Advisory Neighborhood Commissioner for Single Member District 1B10 from 2009-2010.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Eddie was awarded the 2013 Mid-Atlantic Innocence Project’s “Defender of Innocence Award” for his work securing the release of David Boyce, a innocent man wrongfully convicted in Virginia in 1990, and was recognized in 2008 by Legal Bisnow Magazine as a top “30 under 30” attorney in the District of Columbia.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Prior to joining DC Lawyers for Youth full-time, Professor Ferrer worked in private practice at Howrey LLP where he worked on a variety of matters, including juvenile justice policy, immigration law, constitutional law, civil rights law, writs of habeas corpus, white-collar criminal defense, and antitrust law.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Professor Ferrer received his B.S. in Business Administration from the McDonough School of Business at Georgetown University in 2002 and his law degree from Georgetown Law in 2005.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: During his college and law school years, Professor Ferrer worked as a tutor, coach, abuse/neglect compliance intern, special education advocate, and a juvenile defender.
Name: Eduardo Ferrer

Value: Samuel A. Flax joined the Georgetown Law faculty following a 35-year career as a practicing attorney and corporate executive.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: Until its sale in 2017, Professor Flax was the Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Chief Compliance Officer of American Capital, Ltd., a publicly-traded private equity and asset management firm with over $100 billion in assets under management.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: He was a member of American Capital’s investment committee and also an executive officer and director of two publicly-traded mortgage REITs managed by American Capital and of the affiliated European Capital Limited.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: Prior to joining the company in 2005, Professor Flax was a senior partner in the corporate and securities practice group of Arnold & Porter.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: During his 20-year career at the firm, he worked on a wide variety of transactional and counseling matters.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: Previously, Professor Flax was an associate with Morgan, Lewis & Bockius and a law clerk for the Honorable H. Emory Widener, Jr., of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: Professor Flax received a Bachelor of Industrial Engineering from Georgia Tech and a J.D. from Washington & Lee University, where he was Research Editor of the Washington & Lee Law Review.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: In 2018, he was a Fellow in the Advanced Leadership Initiative at Harvard University.
Name: Samuel A. Flax

Value: On April 9, 2021, Professor Fredrickson was named to the Presidential Commission on the Supreme Court of the United States.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Caroline Fredrickson served as the President of the American Constitution Society from 2009-2019, where she helped grow ACS, which now has lawyer chapters across the country, student chapters in nearly every law school in the United States, and thousands of members throughout the nation.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: She was an eloquent spokesperson for ACS and the progressive movement on issues such as civil and human rights, judicial nominations and the importance of the courts in America, marriage equality, voting rights, the role of money in politics, labor law, and anti-discrimination efforts, rule of law, congressional oversight, and separation of powers, among others.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: This fall, she will join Georgetown Law as a Visiting Professor.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Fredrickson has published works on many legal and constitutional issues and is a frequent guest on television and radio, including serving as a regular on-air commentator on impeachment.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: In addition, she regularly contributes opinion pieces for The New York Times, The Washington Post, and other news outlets.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: She is also the author of Under The Bus: How Working Women Are Being Run Over, The Democracy Fix: How to Win the Fight for Fair Rules, Fair Courts, and Fair Elections, and most recently, The AOC Way.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Before joining ACS, Fredrickson served as the Director of the ACLU’s Washington Legislative Office and as General Counsel and Legal Director of NARAL Pro-Choice America.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: In addition, she served as the Chief of Staff to Senator Maria Cantwell, of Washington, and Deputy Chief of Staff to then-Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle, of South Dakota.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: During the Clinton Administration, she served as Special Assistant to the President for Legislative Affairs.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Fredrickson is currently an elected member of the American Law Institute, co-chair of the National Constitution Center’s Coalition of Freedom Advisory Board, a member of If/When/How’s Advisory Board, and on the boards of American Oversight and the National Institute of Money and Politics.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: In 2015 Fredrickson was appointed a member of the Yale Les Aspin Fellowship Committee.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Fredrickson received her J.D. from Columbia Law School with honors and her B.A. from Yale University in Russian and East European Studies summa cum laude, phi beta kappa.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: She clerked for the Hon. James L. Oakes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Name: Caroline Fredrickson

Value: Professor Freeman is the Director of Georgetown’s S.J.D. Program.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: She comes to this position with a diverse portfolio of experiences and interests, including an actual portfolio from her Fine Arts degree and first career as an artist.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: Professor Freeman was a leader in several feminist organizations and the nascent gay rights movement in Washington, DC.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: She was a member of the collective that published a pioneering feminist theory journal, Quest: a feminist quarterly.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: An advocate for DC statehood, she served as elected delegate to the DC Constitutional Convention to draft a constitution in anticipation of eventual statehood.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: She worked on Capitol Hill for Representative (now Senator) Chuck Schumer on the House Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights, and then for the ACLU’s National Prison Project, where she litigated class action cases challenging the constitutionality of conditions of confinement in prisons, jails and juvenile detention facilities across the United States.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: Throughout her legal career she has moved between activism and critical reflection, seeing each as vitally necessary to build a better world and, not coincidentally, to produce first-rate scholarship.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: She believes that success in writing a dissertation over several long years requires both sustained passion about the problem that motivates the scholarship and intellectual discipline to effectively engage it.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: She taught at Washington College of Law and George Washington before coming to Georgetown, first to the Federal Legislation and Administration Clinic, then to Workplace Flexibility 2010, and now Graduate Programs.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: Her scholarly interests are on issues relating to workplace justice, prisons, and career flexibility.
Name: Alexa Freeman

Value: Professor Glaberson rejoins the Civil Litigation Clinic as its Director during the 2021-22 school year, after previously serving as its founding Fellow.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: Since leaving Georgetown, Professor Glaberson has served as a staff attorney focusing on access to justice issues with Public Justice, a national non-profit public interest law firm.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: Prior to helping to found the Civil Litigation Clinic in 2017, Professor Glaberson defended low-income New Yorkers against government interference with their right to parent their children, with Brooklyn Defender Services’
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: Family Defense Practice.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: She received her B.A. magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania, her J.D. cum laude from New York University School of Law, and her L.L.M. with honors from Georgetown University Law Center.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: She previously served as a law clerk to the Honorable Frank Maas in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: She is a member of the bars of New York and the District of Columbia, as well as several federal courts.
Name: Stephanie Glaberson

Value: After graduating from the Law Center in 1970, Professor Goldblatt was an Assistant District Attorney and then a Deputy District Attorney of Philadelphia.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: He has been chair of the American Bar Association Criminal Justice Section Amicus Curiae Briefs Committee (1982-1999).
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: In 1985, he was a member of the ABA committee that issued the report, “Appellate Litigation Skills Training: The Role of the Law Schools.”
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: He served as reporter to the ABA Criminal Justice Section’s Special Committee on Criminal Justice in a Free Society.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: That committee’s report, Criminal Justice in Crisis, was published in 1988.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: In 1992, he was the reporter to the ABA Task Force on Minorities in the Justice System.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: Its July 1992 report was adopted by the ABA and is now being implemented.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: His recent writings in the criminal justice area include several briefs in the United States Supreme Court.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: He has argued three cases in that Court on behalf of Appellate Litigation Clinic clients.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: He currently serves as the Chairperson of the Rules Advisory Committee of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces.
Name: Steven H. Goldblatt

Value: Professor Dr. Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M. works in all fields of industrial property rights and competition law.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: He studied law in Munich, Geneva and Washington D.C. (LL.M. Georgetown, New York Bar Exam).
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: After a legal clerkship the at Berlin High Court, he became assistant professor at Max-Planck-Institute for Foreign and International Copyright, Patent and Competition Law in Munich.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: He held the position of head of the U.S. department.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Afterwards he spent years in private practice.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: He worked for an international law firm with a specialization on intellectual property and information technology law and in a law firm specialized in patent litigation.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Since 2003 he is tenured professor at Albert-Ludwigs-University in Freiburg, Germany where he holds a Chair for Intellectual Property and Competition Law.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: At Freiburg University he lectures on Patent and Copyright Law and on Contract and Tort Law.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: He also teaches mediation.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Between 2011 and March 2017 he has been a Judge at the Patent Division of the Court of Appeals in Düsseldorf.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Maximilian Haedicke has acted as expert witness, as arbitrator and as mediator, especially in national and international patent and licensing proceedings.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: His scholarship engages especially in patent law.
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Maximilian Haedicke is the author of a textbook on patent law (Heymanns 5th ed. 2020) and co-editor and co-author of the Handbook on Patent Law, (2020 Beck and Hart Publishing, 1650 pages).
Name: Maximilian Haedicke, LL.M.

Value: Professor Hagan was the IMF’s General Counsel for fourteen years (2004-2018).
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: In this capacity, Professor Hagan advised the IMF’s management, Executive Board and membership on all legal aspects of the IMF’s operations, including its regulatory, advisory and lending functions.
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: He also led a number of policy initiatives, including, most recently, the reform of the IMF’s anti-corruption policy.
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: Professor Hagan has published extensively on both the law of the IMF and a broad range of issues relating to the prevention and resolution of financial crisis, with a particular emphasis on insolvency and the restructuring of debt, including sovereign debt.
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: Prior to beginning work at the IMF, Professor Hagan was in private practice, first in New York and subsequently in Tokyo.
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: Professor Hagan received his Juris Doctor from the Georgetown University Law Center and also received a Masters of Science in International Political Economy from the London School of Economics and Political Science.
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: During the 2018-2019 Academic year, Professor Hagan has been Visiting Fellow at Oxford University (Exeter College).
Name: Sean Hagan

Value: Professor Stephen P. Hills was appointed the founding director of Georgetown Law’s Business Skills Program in September 2015 after a successful 28 year career at The Washington Post.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Hills served as president and general manager of The Post since September 2002, and in 2008 became president and general manager of Washington Post Media, a multi-platform news brand.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: During his tenure at The Post, he led the transformation of the company culture from a print-centric legacy organization to a digital powerhouse, embracing innovative approaches to technology and creating a culture of ‘fail fast’ experimentation.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: He developed the business case for selling The Post, and led the transition that resulted in The Post being named “Most Innovative Media Company in the World” by Fast Company in 2015.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: The extraordinary record of innovations created under Hill’s leadership include:   •         Digital Partner Program.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Created millions of new Washington Post consumers by developing innovative partnerships with more than three hundred newspapers and digital publishers.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: •         ARC – a digital publishing software suite of products created by the Washington Post engineering team that is now sold under a SaaS model.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: •         Greater Washington Publishing.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Created a niche Print and Internet publishing operation that became the model for the newspaper industry and generated tens of millions of dollars in operating profits.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: •         Express.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Created one of the most successful free distribution commuter publications in the country, which also generated tens of millions in profits.   •
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: An ever-growing array of Washington Post digital products on a wide variety of platforms.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Professor Hills’s career started after college when he used $2,000 in savings to co-found The Bay City Business Journal in the San Francisco Bay Area, which – under his leadership – grew within two years to the largest controlled circulation business publication in Northern California.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Professor Hills is proud to have started his career as a sales representative for the Fuller Brush Company in 1979 in San Francisco.
Name: Stephen P. Hills

Value: Professor Hills graduated from Yale University in 1981 and received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1987.
Name: Stephen P. Hills
